This game is absolutely amazing. I was really on the fence about this purchase because I thought that this concept would get old fast, but I'm 23 hours in over the course of around 4 days and I'm still excited to keep playing.  First of all, this game would probably be best described as 'tense' instead of 'scary.' I suppose this could vary from person to person, but considering my background of absolutely zero appreciation for horror movies and games, most people will not find this game scary.  The store page and countless twitch streamers will give you a great idea of the gameplay, so I won't explain how the game works, but I'll just list a couple issues/aspects that could turn people off from the game.  -No communication with survivors while in a match (Personally I think this is kind of cool.) -Some achievements are not working properly -A few bugs, such as survivors getting 'glitched' and not being able to pick them up as the killer or heal them as a survivor -No actual matchmaking.  -Killers host the server, so a laggy killer will make you lag as survivor. (However, you can test your connection to the killer in lobby by typing a message and observing the delay before it appears in chat.)  I don't believe the developers have plans to add communication, but I am almost certain that the other issues will be fixed shortly. There have been numerous updates to fix bugs and add content.   This game is extremely fun to play and I can't recommend it enough. The only thing that has really affected me is not being able to play with friends online (edit: you can now survive with friends).  Edit: Removed issues that were fixed   TL;DR: Awesome gameplay with a few issues that shouldn't ruin an experience.

I felt like I needed to write a review to help others, and clear up an issue people have with the game. First off the game is wondedrful and unique. I love how the developers wanted to capture the essence of human error in the game with both surviving and hunting. As of right now you can play with friends in a private lobby, and not recieve experience, but the devs. have said they are going to add a party system where you and friends can play together in public matches. They just didn't want it on release, and now I am not entirely sure why they would do this, but I am assuming it is because they don't want a premade team of survivors playing against a new killer and then winning by a landslide. They may also want to get the community more willing to talk and communicate with randoms, who knows. So for those who have decided that you will never get this game if you can't play with friends you WILL be able to, just...not right now.

I DEFINITELY RECOMMEND.  If you're looking for the kind of game that never needs improvements, balance changes, bug fixes, add-ons, etc, than first of all: where do I find such a game? Second: this game is probably not for you.  Dead by Daylight is an amazing experience. It's a game that does a lot of things that you don't see much at all right now. The game has some problems, (some worse than others) but if you are a somewhat patient person, and enjoy unique experiences, this is a great place to look.  There are lots of good people who are loyal to this game. Dead by Daylight is really something special in terms of community, and content. Like the fact that there's already two new 'Chapters' out, and they're great additions to the game too. It's really an exciting thing to try and guess what's next. There are tons of people with public ideas on possible killers, maps, etc.  The game can be very difficult to start out, however, I enjoyed it from the start, and I was already expecting a lot out of it. And I'd like to add a little bit of (very important) detail to something that many players point out in both positive and negitive reviews. That is, the difficulty. Sure it can be really hard as a new player. But it isn't so much because it takes a very long time to level up - which it does - but instead it is simply that you have to learn the way it works. That's all. I even sometimes play as one of the survivors that I still have at level one, just to experience the thrill of having no perks, items, etc. It is however very difficult to do this with a killer. Being a low level killer, kind of sucks sometimes, but that gets better too as the game grows.  I think this game deserves really great reviews. This is my only review I've written, and I usually don't really do things like this, but I really want to see this game turn around!  In case you're still reading this, I play as both killer and survivor, and thank you for reading!

UPDATED REVIEW The game is a 4v1 survival/hunting game. Basically you can be The Killer or The Survivors. There are 5 different killers with 5 different ways to play them. Trapper - traps, Hillbilly - instantly incaps, Wraith - cloaks, ♥♥♥♥ - I mean Nurse - teleports, and Shape - stalks/instatly incaps. The goal is to sacrifice or kill all the survivors before they can escape. As for the Survivors. There 6 different survivors with 6 different characteristics. There is Dwight - supports/boosts, Claudette - supports/healer, Meg - agility/adredaline, Jake - sabotage/calm, Nea -stealth/agility, and Laurie - spotter/baiter. There goal is to activate the remaining generators to open the escape gate. They also have to rely on teamwork. And hide from the killer. In my previous review I said how there was no teamchat. Well they added a chat in lobby and after the game ends. So you can do some preplanning with teammates. Otherwise use Teamspeak or something. I also complained about servers. They have improved them working a lot better. (9/10) ORINGIAL REVIEW The game play is great. Extremely fun and intense at moments. Though there is no team chat which results in a lack of teamwork. Sadly I find myself carrying the game. Another side note to consider is that the servers are absolute crap. Half the time the servers disconnected or steam just goes down. Really kills the fun. I'd give it a 6/10 until some changes are made. Please release an update soon.

Played since the Beta and honestly it has been pretty fun. The atmosphere when you're the killer is amazing and also the nice feature of your heart beating when the killer is near is an awesome niche to the game.  Now quite a bit of people are complaining that there's no party system or chat system but if you think about it, the DEVs would've thought of implementing a party system just like every other game but they didn't put it in it for one factor, being fairness.   The first reasoning for the no party system is because it would be extremely one sided for the Survivors to win.   To reinforce my first reasoning of the party system is because of communication. Because the survivors aren't able to use their mics or type in-game, they aren’t able to know where their teammates are to go distract the killer, heal their teammates or work on the generators. In saying that, this would give the killer fair fighting chance to win. For example, when playing by myself in the beta I would usually lose half of the matches I've played. However when I was playing with my mates while communicating via skype to which we pretty much won every match.  Yes it would be better to have a party system because it’s quite annoying putting up with people leaving and re-joining to join their friends but hey, when life gives you lemons, make lemonade and don't be a little ♥♥♥♥♥ about it.

If you like classic slasher movies and that kind of stuff I am sure you will enjoy this one.   Dead by Daylight is really interesting game. Asymmetrical multiplayer in its core is really similar to Evolve. There is one killer and 4 survivors. Killer wants to slaughter these horny teenagers and survivors just try to escape. There is no way to kill the Killer so as a survivor you need to hide and work together to survive. Also it provides the horror element to this game making you feel helpless. This game provides 2 different gameplay experiences which are both equally enjoyable. It offers variety even if the gamemode is always the same.   When you see people who have written reviews of this game, you can see that quite many have several hundred hours of playtime. That is because this game is addictive. There is not many maps to discover or interesting stories to find but what makes this game addictive is competition. I place this game in to the category of 'Skill addiction'. Much like many mobas and competetive shooters, this game has a steep learning curve and a ranking system. Getting better and unlocking new perks for your characters keeps you 'hooked' and the gameplay experience fresh even when there is little variation.   If you can look past some rough edges, bugs and salty adversaries, you will find very compelling and addictive multiplayer experience.   8,5/10

19, July, 2016 Dead by Daylight is a multiplayer, competitive, survival, horror game which typically is played as a 1v4, 1v3, 1v2 or 1v1.  The setting is in some sort of abandoned park, or field, etc (different maps) at night where 1-4 survivors are trapped and must attempt to escape. The reason why they must escape is because lurking in the area with them is a demonic, cold-blooded serial-killer. The killer who is controlled by 1 player in the match must kill/sacrifice as many survivors as possible. Sounds like a pretty straight-forward matchup. However it is not as easy as it seems.  In each map there are 2 main exits which are closed and dysfunctional, as well as around 7 stationary generators spread around the area. In order the power the main exists, the survivors must repair a certain number generators (typically depending on the amount of survivors in the match (4 survivors = 5 generators. 3 survivors = 4 generators. etc)) Each generator takes a vaguely large amount of time to repair and while survivors are repairing them they are constantly under the heart-pounding pressure of encountering the killer.  The killer's job isn't entirely simple either. When the killer finds a survivor he must strike them (generally twice) with their primary weapon in order to seize them from running and down them. From there the killer cannot physically kill the survivors (unless a certain 'perk' is used). His job is to pick them up and hang them on sacrificial hooks spread around the map. The hooks keep the survivors stationary and sets a long time limit where a spider-like, speared creature (best description I can give) forms around the hook post and attempts to kill the survivor. The survivors can be saved while hung up though.   At this point in time (July 19, 2016) the killer player can select 1 of 3 different killers, each with a different ability. One carries around beartraps which can be set anywhere and seize wandering survivors. One has a cloaking bell which can turn the killer mostly invisible. And also one with a chainsaw that can be used to charge at and completely down any survivors that make contact.  The game as well as being challenging includes many more mechanics and features than it appears. When performing tasks such as repairing generators or healing teammates, the game randomly displays 'skill checks' in order the make the tasks more pressuring and challenging. Upon failing a skill check, the completion bar will move down slightly and will also causes a very audible sound, potentially attracting the killer. Upon succeeding a skill check, the bar moves skips a few seconds and rewards the player extra game points. There are also storage crates around the map which contain useful items for survivors such as medkits for assisting in healing other survivors or yourself, toolboxes for assisting in repairing generators or sabotaging hooks and other mechanical objects, or a flashlight which can be used to blind and stun the killer when necessary.  There are many ways for survivors to counter the killer's wrath including vaulting over slightly raised objects or windows, pushing down barricades in front of him and potentially stunning them, blinding them with the flashlight, hiding in cabinets, or planting themselves in camouflaged positions in order the lure the killer away.  There are many other mechanics in-game which I would love to talk about but need to keep this review not as long. The game also has a ranking system used to truly compete with other players and become more skilled at the game. There are also a variety of customization options, items, perks and add-ons for the characters and killers.  The game at this point in time isn't perfect, as there are many bugs and in-game features which make the game less fun and more frustrating at times. However, what we have right now is a creative, fun and interactive competitive game that tests and rewards the player's ability to remain vigilant, keep focused, be stealthy, stay alert, and be altruistic and supportive to your fellow survivors. And always remember that 'death is not an escape'  Pros: - Incredible variety of mechanics - Intriguing gameplay - Audio gives players paranoia - Overwhelmingly terrifying moments - Greatly tests player's gameplay abilities - Variety of customization and add-ons - Enjoyable when played with friends - Potential epic and satisfying moments  Cons: - Some frustrating mechanics and features - Confusing ranking system - Non reusable items and perks - Over-powered favouring to quickly skilled players - Glitches (July 19, 2016) - Not a lot the game has to offer (July 19, 2016) - Poorly optimized (July 19, 2016)  7/10 Recommended for players interested in multiplayer, survival horror, strategy, and competitive gameplay.

Ok, I haven't played DbD as long as many others but I'd still like to write a little review :) While this game is still far from perfect I (usually) really enjoy playing, especially together with friends. Obviously the course of the game doesn't change that much but still every round is a bit different and it never gets old for me if the killer passes by without noticing me crouching in high grass. As far as I can tell the waiting time to get into a lobby has been successfully reduced by a large amount and for the last few times I played I never had trouble with getting kicked out of a lobby. The biggest problem for me is still that killers camp and then the other survivors don't want to come near the hook - perfectly understandable but that really makes the game short for me.  All in all I really like this game and if you're not too keen on getting ranks and levelling like mad it can be great fun.

This game is getting a lot of hate right now. There are problems, but the gameplay is pretty fun. Most of the people having problems with the game post discussion threads, despite stickied posts on it and about two dozen others like it, because they did not take the time to investigate the game prior to.  The game does not have ranked mode with friends currently. Why? - It creates an unfair advantage as the friends can use VOIP to coordinate against the killer. - ^ This ruins the immersion and is not the way the devs want it to be played. - This issue was noticed early in development, it is being worked on; however, this requires balance so that the killer is not underpowered. - It's far too easy for a friendly killer and a friendly survivor to farm a crapload of blood points.  Solution? There's a mode for it and it's the top priority of the dev team; it will allow up to 3 friends to play (based on current information). They've been working on it for over a week, so bare with them or honestly GTFO and stop whining. No one gives a crap about you refunding.  There's no microphone or chat. What kind of teamwork game doesn't let you communicate? - Communication, microphone or text, ruins the immersion of the game. - It creates an unfair advantage 4v1.  - The devs specifically did not want it as a feature. - You CAN get by without communicating. If your team sucks, they suck; however if you find good players, you will notice an unspoken communication between them, as with all games. - This is NOT necessarily a teamwork based game. You can be as selfish as you want if it gets you to the end. It's all up to your playstyle.  You can't rebind keys. - On the way, I believe it was 2nd or 3rd in the dev to do list.  You can't change specific graphic settings. - ^^ It's either 2nd or 3rd on the dev to do list. - You should be able to change settings by forcing them with your GPU's control center.  The game is poorly optimized. - This is true and it needs to be improved upon. The Beta ran FAR smoother than the current build is for me.  Sabotaging costs too much toolbox charges; flashlights barely work. - Toolboxes were pretty OP during the beta, but they overnerfed them to be absolute crap. Flashlights hardly ever work. They need to be buffed/fixed.  There's hook graphical errors that cause players to float/perform weird animations/be entirely non interactable. - This needs to be fixed and has been a problem since beta. It was less of a game breaking bug in beta.  Killers can teleport out of map, thus making the game unplayable for them, by hitting a player simutaneously performing an action. - Been in since beta, but is fairly rare in my experience.  Ranked mode is glitchy/requires too much/I lose ranked progress when killer DCs. - Losing ranked progress while the host DCs has been in since beta, you used to also lose your items, but they fixed that. I don't know if it preserves add ons or offerings. If you find an item, you get to keep it. - It used to be far easier to rank up as you could 1-3 pips based on doing okay, doing great or doing perfectly. It's too hard now to get even 2 pips. - Despite getting enough points for a pip, I've still not gotten pips/lost pips.  Play with friends mode doesn't have matchmaking of any kind. - This needs to be addressed as well. They should also have an optional VC option on friend lobbies that runs in the game (I've heard people speak before in lobbies, so I can't imagine it would be too difficult to implement).  Despite these problems, I still really enjoy this game. I think it could potentially replace L4D2 as a horror-esque, extremely fun to play coop game. If you want to wait a few patches before buying it, go ahead. I totally recommend it. The dev team is passionate but quite small. I intend to stick it out further in hopes the game will improve.

Summary:  Overall very unique and compelling gameplay. Would recommend if it seems interesting to you, as it is great value and promises to continue to be in the future. Still a bit rough around the edges to put it midly (at launch it could have passed for an early access title and it could be argued that it still does), but the relatively small dev team is very communicative and seems open to changing their direction to varying degrees based on community feedback. Some bugs have been fixed, others have appeared. Because of this, what follows may be quite subject to change. However, the fact that I still play this game despite its imperfections speaks volumes about its strengths.    Pros:   -The combination of excitement/panic you can feel when you first start playing, especially as a survivor, I haven't quite felt in many other games. This lessens a bit with experience and game knowledge, but that brings its own enjoyment. I wouldn't call it 'horror' though, as it doesn't quite have jump-scares, although I have jerked my mouse in surprise/fear when making a mistake as a survivor. It seems more like a 'Thriller', imho.  -Unique asymetrical multiplayer gameplay. Very different overall feel and power differential than other titles in the same vein.  -Procedurally generated map design. Overall, a particular map will have a similar feel, but will differ in many game-altering ways. The varying locations of objectives, killer hooks and basement, initial spawns, exits and some other doodads on the map will make each game unique. This combined with the increasing killer variability adds a lot of replay value.  -Deep progression system. End-game builds can take hundreds of hours to achieve, unless you get very lucky (see below). There are also cosmetics and other currently minor advantages unlockable by 'prestiging' a character, although it resets all other progress for that character.  -Great value for the money. The devs have hinted that eventual, unconfirmed, paid content (although with maps remaining free to all so as to not split the playerbase) would also tend towards this high value.  -Very different mechanics amongst killers making varied playstyles necessary for both survivors and killers. The game is relatively easy to learn but many aspects which vary widely between killers have a decently high skillcap (e.g.: staying hidden/searching hiding spots well, evading the killer/not losing found survivors, prioritizing objectives smartly, reacting to opponent(s)'s strenghts/weaknesses, possible mind-games, etc.)   -Fantastic audio design that is an integral part of the gameplay. The killer's proximity to you as a survivor will alter the soundtrack, and is a key game mechanic.  -Compelling enough of a game to keep me playing tons despite many cons.   Cons:  -Bugs, glitches: matchmaking issues especially with recently added 'Survive with Friends' mode, several gameplay-affecting bugs/issues, certain remaining game-breaking glitches and other esthetic issues once again make this feel almost like a late early access title at times. This is getting better with time, though some new bugs also have popped up with additions to the game.  -Peer-to-peer multiplayer connection. There are no game servers. The survivors connect to a killer that hosts the game, which ends if the killer leaves/disconnects. The ping of the survivors is therefore based on their connection to the killer, and there is currently no in-game ping indicator, though people have found ways to try to estimate this value. The devs have stated that the game would not have released if it were not for this design decision, and have expressed interest in eventually changing this, but it does not seem likely in the near future, as I gather from their statements.  -Current end-game meta seems pretty strongly established. A few 'Perks' that are initially unique character abilities can eventually be taught to other characters. This combined with current strengths of these abilities makes some of them practically mandatory, and others essentially useless. Player builds therefore more or less converge over time. However, the devs have already made significant balance changes in response to community feedback and their stats, which does seem to have slightly increased options.  -Long grind to achieve aforementioned best character builds, a downside to the deep progression system. To be able to play with the very best setup will take several dozens of hours if you're lucky, and most likely in the order of 100 hours or more. You can still have fun and be very viable without any perks whatsoever with experience, but it is initially very tough to play with no or suboptimal perks.  -Some RNG. While not overwhelming, it still factors in quite a bit. Above, I mentioned you might get lucky and progress your character more quickly. This refers to perk aquisition, which requires points earned through gameplay to unlock, but appears in a random sequence. You may get an essential perk very early, or not stumble across it for a very long time.  -Limited options (audio levels and some detailed graphics options). While these affect gameplay, they have stated that some additionnal options are coming.   -Relatively high minimum requirements. Because things like detailed foliage, fog/mist, lighting and shadows are essential gameplay elements related to stealth, some machines just won't run it well. The game seems poorly optimized, so expect your machine to under-perform compared to other games

This game totally shook me. Firstly, I saw a youtuber playing it, was like meh, what's this game, another boring thing on the market, but when I watched 1 episode, I simply loved it, and wanted so bad to buy it, and here I am. 1) This game has great graphics, everything is creepy, as it should be. 2) Interesting mechanics, such as : Perk/offering/addon combinations, crows and sprinting giving away your position, generators repairing strategies, and even more.. 3) Costumization is also a good part here, different characters, unique perks, clothing. (DLC'S) 4) As a killer/survivor type of game, I find this one really cool and has a bright future, so many things can be changed : new killers, new maps, new survivors, new perks that bring new mechanics..  So the point of the game is to play as a killer/survivor :  As a survivor you have to repair a total of 5 generators whilst various things can happen, repairing a generators has a small skill-check so you must be paying attention to that otherwise the killer knows you're there and running around with SHIFT leaves red marks everywhere and dissapear after about 4-5 seconds. Use grass,trees, lockers to hide from the killer.. When all generators are powered up, 2 gates show up, open which one you decide by various reasons, and you win. If you remain alone, there's also a hatch somewhere spawned in the map, you can escape by it.  As a killer, you need to of course stop the survivors from repairing generators and sabotaging. You have an unique weapon depending on what killer you are, with a secondary function (ex. invisibility, placing traps,teleporting..). Hitting a player once lowers their HP to another stage (bleeding), survivor yells because of pain and leaves blood on the ground (blood dissapears after 3-4 seconds) but in exchange, he gets a boost of speed for 1-2 seconds and you need to do an animation in which you clean your weapon or something (making you slow for a bit). Hitting them the second time, you down them, and they can be picked up by you, they can wiggle so they escape out of your grasp, but if you get in time to a hook, you can place them, and the sacrifice begins, that's how survivors die. Survivors can also unhook each other. But of course, strategies come and games will always be different.  I totally recommend trying it at least, it's worth your time (played it 3-4 days in a row, 6 hours a day or so, I was and still am really into it).

I’ll start off by saying this game is definitely one of those games that gives you an adrenaline rush. The concept is simple, complete objectives to escape the killer. In my opinion the mechanics are fairly straight forward and the gameplay is fun for the most part, however this game definitely needs a lot of improvement.  The game feels like an early access game since it is fairly buggy and the matching making feels very unbalanced at the moment. For the most part the level design in the game was great for the type of gameplay, but there were a couple of maps that felt a bit too cluttered and you either couldn’t escape or couldn’t get the player to the hook. In some of the maps, the jumping response times were either delayed or non-existent. I only played a few rounds, but I can see the gameplay getting very repetitive and an additional game mode would be nice, especially if it was one where the survivors had to do objectives to trap or kill the killer (make the objectives a challenge to complete so it isn’t super easy). I found the matchmaking to be a bit unstable, as me or my friends were getting kicked, or there was problems with the host when we were doing a group of 5. In summary, if you want a flawless game, this definitely isn’t for you.  Some positive things about the game however, are the concept is really cool and as I previously stated, it does give you an adrenaline rush. Again, most of the level design was well done for this type of game concept. After a while, four survivors fill the lobby, all finally readying up for a bit of a game. I hover briefly over each to check levels and names: One is called 'Drizzy is AIDS.' I silently tell myself that this player is going to end up being a real jackass.  I run around the level, snatching mo'♥♥♥♥as up in bear traps and slinging people onto meat hooks. It's well-fought, but the team doesn't work together, and divided they fall. After a few minutes, I've gotten three sacrifices. Notably absent from the list? You've guessed it--Mr. AIDS.  Drizzy doesn't even bother to try and start generators. After about five more minutes of running around looking for him, I decide to just wait for him to disconnect or try to escape, passing the time by reading some guides for killers that are new to the game.  Ten more minutes pass. No movement. Nothing in the guides tell me about these sorts of players, but it doesn't take long before it dawns on me: Drizzy is hiding somewhere, trying to force me into quitting in a fit of rage. I smile as I begin the tedious task of checking every damned locker in the level.  Locker after locker with no Drizzies inside pass before I realize that this guy is probably hiding where he assumes I'll never look. I head to the basement, replete with blood, gore, and baling hooks, only to begin checking lockers. I finally get to the furthest locker and open it up, and would you guess who was cowering inside? Drizzy! The reunion is sweet as the P.o.S. starts screaming, right before I lovingly slide his wriggling body onto a sharpened, curved piece of pig iron.  Drizzy doesn't plan on staying there, however: As I watch, he somehow frees himself from my beautiful contraption, only to fall to the floor limping and bleeding. I observe somewhat detachedly, a grin spreading across my face, as our hapless protagonist attempts to run upstairs.  A crude machete cuts Drizzy down as he reaches the top flight, leaving him crawling on the cold stone floors in pools of his own blood. I find myself standing over him, watching curiously as his life meter drains; he drags himself around the map, grunting as he does so.  After about three minutes of me waiting, his life meter finally has only a sliver left. Humming a sweet little show tune to myself, I pick up our friend and drag his ♥♥♥ back to the basement, throwing him up on a hook yet again. I set a bear trap under his feet as he dangles there, looking quite troubled, indeed.   As Drizzy attempts, yet again, to drop himself from the hook into the waiting jaws of the bear trap below, our eyes finally meet. Gazes lock as the pain of torment, loss, and even betrayal simultaneously flash across that beautifully-lotioned face of his. I smile for the last time as I whisper softly to our good friend Drizzy: '-I- am the AIDS, Drizzy... -I- am the AIDS.'   I could have sworn that he nodded, eyes full of recognition as they started to turn gray. He stops struggling, going completely limp. I stroke his sweet, sweet afro as netherworldly appendages arrive to impale him. '-I- am the AIDS, Drizzy. -I- am the AIDS.'  11/10 would be the AIDS again

I am in the mix about this game. Update: They have announced that there will be a party system implemented :]  (When it isn’t buggy) Positives Survivor This game does a good job of making it atmospheric and a truly chilling experience. I like the fact that the game has skill checks and makes you make a decision. Do you focus on the skill check more or your surroundings? Feeling the heartbeat or the bell go off can send someone into a panic and wonder what is going to happen to them next. That feeling of escaping the killer’s grasp and living at the end is amazing. The game also questions how you are morally. Do you try and save everyone or are you selfish? Do you work on the generators or let everyone else do the dirty work? If you scratch my back will I scratch yours? I have had multiple games where I will save a fellow survivor but that player wouldn’t do the same for me when I got captured or I just leave my whole team behind. The perks and offerings you can obtain are also very good. From toolboxes to medkits this game does a good job I believe on the items you can obtain. Offerings allow you to get extra blood points, put you on a desirable map, etc. If you are the last survivor and your team was slaughtered the game gives you the option of either doing the remaining generators or finding the hatch to escape. This feature is truly amazing because it gives the last person an actual chance to escape and win the game.  Killer Being the killer can be a thrilling experience. Your job is pretty simple, kill the survivors. But I believe it goes bigger than that. You manage the map and check generators to make sure the survivors aren’t trying to turn them on. I’ve had games where I actually herded survivors into a certain on the map because they were too scared to go anywhere else. Putting that fear into the enemy team gives you this feeling that you are really a killer. Cutting down the survivors efforts is really entertaining. Each killer has their own unique way of doing things. The trapper basically sets traps at pivotal points in the map or random locations to attempt to trap someone and take them to a hook for them to be sacrificed. The hillbilly is very good at covering ground and chasing people down. With his chainsaw you can easily put a survivor into a downed state after one sprint. The wraith is very good at sneaking up on survivors seeing as he is invisible and when he goes invisible there is no heartbeat to tell you that he is near till he uncloaks. The bell signals him going invisible or coming out from it and I enjoy putting that fear into someone. Each have their own unique playstyle imo and I found it to be enjoyable.  Negatives There are so many bugs in this game right now that it can ruin all the positives. From people being able to teleport to not being able to vault through a window. I have had my fair share of bugs while playing this game. Lag is another issue that I have ran into a lot. The fact that people can rage quit and that I can earn absolutely zero points for that is ridiculous. I don’t think it’s fair to the killer that someone can do that. But at the same time the killer can quit and I have lost rank points because of that. Another issue is that there is no party system at all in the game. The only way you can play with friends atm is to go into a private match and earn no XP. I can see why the devs would want to do this because then you and your friends can communicate via 3rd party system. But here comes my next issue….there is no way to communicate with the randoms that you have. There is no gesture system, voice lines, or voice chat, absolutely nothing to communicate. You can only type in the lobby before the game starts. So basically you are stuck with 3 other random people that you have can’t say a word to in-game. How does a game that begs for coop and working with each other for a common goal have no communication system? It is unrealistic that the survivors wouldn’t try to talk or signal at all in the situation that they are in.  Opinions I find this game to have it’s ups and downs. There are moments that I am having so much fun trying to run away but that can instantly be ruined by a game breaking bug. If I were anyone I would wait on this purchase till a patch releases stating they fixed some of the bugs. At the current moment this game has too many bugs and it can really ruin the experience. Some of the bugs that were present in the beta are still present in the full game. I would also like to see another way to kill the survivors rather than just putting them on a hook. It kind of gets stale after awhile of just playing these interesting killers but doing the same way to kill a survivor. I feel each killer should of had their own way of killing the survivor. I really enjoy the game for what it is though. I just hope they improve on it.

Okay, I'm giving this game a positive rating but my review is going to be very critical.  This game is undoubtedly very fun and I definitely recommend it, but there are some serious issues that are going to need to be addressed.  To start, the game has no dedicated servers. Whoever is playing the Killer is hosting the game. So, you're at the mercy of the Killer's internet connection in order to have a stable/satisfying game. Unfortunately, there's going to be people playing as the Killer with absolutely garbage internet and as a result, the game becomes so laggy that it can literally become uplayable. There's also rumors of killers actually cheating by abusing this and deliberately making their game laggy to give them an advantage while playing. (lagswitch) I don't know how they go about doing it but it's definitely within the realm of possibility.  If adding dedicated servers is out of the question (though that would be the ideal solution), a ping indicator in the lobby before the game begins would give the survivors an idea if their game will be playable or a lagfest when it starts. At least players would know to avoid games where their ping is in the thousands (at which point it's only the people deliberately cheating you'd have to worry about).  My second major complaint is less technical and more balance related; infinite jukes. In a perfect world, the game would function essentially like this. The killer runs faster than survivors so he can catch them. In order for survivors to have a chance, they have to play smart by hiding. When they get spotted, they run for their lives, looking for a way to lose the killer so they can go back to hiding from him. When a survivor runs, they leave a trail of chicken scratch marks in their wake that the Killer can see to track them down. This can be avoided by not running. But first the survivor has to make the Killer lose their trail by confusing him. This can be accomplished several ways. These methods include vaulting through windows/obstacles (to which the Killer can follow albeit extremely slowly) knocking obstacles in the Killer's path via pallets, stunning the Killer by hitting him with the aforementioned pallets, blinding the killer with a flashlight, etc. If successful, the survivor's skill will be rewarded when the Killer loses their trail and they can go back to hiding and working on a way to escape. Unfortunately, there's one very serious flaw with the game's current design. Infinite jukes.  There are several sections in every single map where there are multiple obstacles a survivor can vault past very close to one another. As a result, when the Killer chases a survivor to one of these spots, unless the survivor misplays, it's literally not possible for the killer to capture the survivor. They simply need to vault past an obstacle and when the Killer either follows (again, very slowly) or tries to go around, the survivor can simply move to the next obstacle and vault again. Rinse and repeat indefinitely.  There is one Killer that has a chance at countering this problem, The Trapper, which can set bear traps in an attempt to prevent this abusive mechanic, but it's far from a perfect solution. Survivors have methods of disarming and even destroying these traps. Not to mention the other two killers have no legitimate counter to this whatsoever. So quite literally speaking, a pro-survivor has, and I'm not exaggerating here, literally has 0 chance at losing this game. They simply can't be caught. They can survive indefinitely and the only chance the Killer has at capturing these players is hoping they misplay at some point so they can land a lucky hit. However, this infinite juking is not difficult at all, so the chances at misplaying are very small.  Now, I believe the devs understand that this is an issue and are working towards a solution that hopefully everyone can be happy with. Until then though, the game can be very frustrating for both Killers and survivors. I mean, it's no fun as a survivor to simply hop through windows repeatedly because a stubborn Killer won't give up and it's no fun for the Killer knowing it's simply not possible to capture a stubborn survivor that won't stop abusing this obviously broken mechanic. Unfortunately, until survivors simply no longer have this as an option, it'll continue to be abused time and time again.  Unfortunately, there are also other issues that are not in the game's favor in the way of bugs. This game has an unhealthy number of bugs, some of which are quite minor while others are very disruptive to the game. The bugs as of this review that I personally am aware of are as follows:  *Survivor getting stuck being unable to move. There seem to just be certain spots on the map that if you're unlucky enough to run across it, you'll just get stuck. (Haven't noticed it on a Killer yet and this is actually quite rare)  *Survivor disconnecting, yet not being registered as a disconnect, leaving an unresponsive invulnerable survivor, preventing the game for the Killer from ending (forcing them to quit, which results in no points and a down-rank)  *Blank spots in the Bloodweb (the way in which you unlock new abilities by spending earned points). You spend points to unlock items and abilities in a web, unlocking one thing will open the path to unlocking the next thing and then the next thing(s) etc. There are times one spot in the path will simply be blank, preventing you from not only purchasing what should have been there, but blocking the path to any item/ability that purchase would have led to. Very disruptive to the game.  *Various graphical glitches that range from funny looking characters to a game breaking 'nothing on the map loaded, so I'm running into invisible walls!' (the latter may very well be lag related and not actually a bug).  *The killer occasionally getting stuck in place while carrying a surivor that disconnects.  There are probably other bugs, but these are the ones I can recall off the top of my head.  So, you may be wondering, 'Well damn Casm! If this game has as many issues as you're saying it has, why the hell are you giving this game a positive review!?' The simple answser? Because when it's plays right, the game is just crazy good and loads of fun. I'm also giving the devs some benefit of the doubt in assuming the most of the disruptive bugs are going to be fixed and that the infinite juking will ultimately be balanced. The bugs, while plentiful are relatively rare and when you do come across players that have enough respect to not abuse obviously broken mechancs, the cat and mouse style of hide and seek is extremely addictive and entertaining for both survivors and killers. In short, right now the game is good and when these issues are eventually (hopefully) addressed, the game will be that much better.  I will stipulate though that the ball is very much in the developer's court and in order for this game to maintain this positive review, (and probably others) these issues HAVE to be addressed. If enough time passes and the game is still riddled with the flaws laid out here, then I just won't be able to continue recommending the game as I currently am.

This game is intense. Intense in the fact that it can touch both sides of the spectrum : One being helpless and terrified and the other feeling a sense of tremendous guilty pleasure when stabing a helpless survivor.  I would like to think of this game as a really good horror film that lingers on in your mind for weeks after the fact and for a horror movie enthusiast I more than welcome this. It has a really unique set of characters (Mostly from the killer aspect) and a really fun objective orientated style gameplay both for the killer and the surivors. When you combine these two elements with the amazing settings of the maps you get a really good product.  One of the best reasons why I personally like this game aside from the actual gameplay and amazing detail into character/map design is the fact that ping isn't a major factor in this game. As a person living in South Africa I can firmly say that I play an abundance of online competitive games with a 200-250 ping handicap, and it's increadibly frustrating. However, in this game it isn't the case, ping hardly affects me and I can play without this handicap and it feels great. Don't get me wrong I obviously still have that ping, but it isn't a major factor.   There are a few issues I have with this game though. 1: The bugs, the bugs with mostly the trapper killer and the survivor being bugged in a trap whilst rescuing their friend. It really destroys the mood however funny it may be the first 1-3 times it happens. This is just 1 of the most common bugs I have come across and it really destroys both the immersive experience as well as that current game. There are a few more bugs but its best not to divulge further into them or else I would be nit-picking. 2: Alot of disconnecting randomly for no reason, due to 'anti-cheat'. Followed the solutions people came up with and yes fair enough they worked to a certain extent, but only to have the game disconnect 3 games following.  3: Matchmaking; The matchmaking in this game feels really inconsistent. I will be in a group of 20 ranked survivors from fresh installs only to have a rank 1 killer with a long list of perks and experience. Yes, I know how matchmaking works and it's not the easiest thing to do with 100% efficiency but that seems odd, especially since it happens more than 50% of the time to me and my group of friends.  All that aside, the game feels and looks great and I really hope the devs keep releasing new content that we all could get excited for.  I would highly recommend this game if you're a fan of horror games that are done properly that can give you a good scare even after your 50th time playing it.  If I were to give this a numeral rating I would say 7/10.

UPDATED review (after more hours of playing it)  The game still is absolutely great. With that, I mean that the concept and the style of gaming. However, it is not near perfection.  The match-making in 'survive with friends' still is terrible. When there is a round of 4 people (filling the survivor spots available), sometimes you have to wait up to 45 minutes to find a match and then, one has to be lucky so the killer does not leave the lobby because he knows he has to play against a group of four people that will most likely communicate. Unfortunately, I do not know how the matchmaking works in DbD, but I wonder if it so difficult to make that a full survivor group gets one killer assigned to them.  Also, there are of course different ways to play a game, for survivors as well as for killers, but is massive camping really a good way? It is terribly annoying to have a camping killer, and it often (also heard that from friends and other players) leads to quitting the game - because when I e.g. play four matches, there's at least two of the killers that are camping. It's not great for those who want to save people from hooks, but also for the hooked one.  Before someone complains and says, this would be necessary to get enough points - that is not true. Just check out e.g. tru3ta1ent or other high-ranked DbD-players. Most of them aren't camping. Also, for most survivor players, it is alright when the killer walks around in the area around the hooked survivor. Standing directly in front of the hook, however, is not.  I no longer think a game mechanic that makes it unable for the killer to stay near the hook would be good, but maybe after the match, an up and downvoting system or sth. like that is an idea? Or that the amount of bloodpoints the killer receives for sacrificing is decreased when being in a 10 meter radius around a hooked one.   I appreciate the change in the game where you no longer see the rank and level of the other survivors. This stopped lobby hopping almost entirely and with it, had a positive effect on the game.  Again, the matchmaking is still annoying. I don't think it is a good matchmaking when all four survivors are low-level (Anything under rank 16 and three perks or less for me) and low-rank (anything from 20-16), and they have to play against top-level top-ranked killer. That results in a heavily unbalanced game - which is annoying.  Something, that in my opinion is still missing (but, I imagine it is not easy to implement), is the private lobby leveling. I hope that one will never be able to spend their private-lobby gained bloodpoints for their online character, but I expect this won't happen. But for private fun, it would be nice to have a seperate leveling.   Now that the release is already a while back, it's very nice to see that there's still so many people playing all the time - which is positively about the game and shows the potential it has. But only because there are so many players, it does not mean the game can be neglected. There's (in my personal opinion) still A LOT to do. But I think and hope, the developers won't fool around with it. Despite as of lately there has been a stream of salty reviews, I find Dead by Daylight to be one of the funnest multiplayer games I've ever played in a long time.  My personal opinion is I enjoy games with:  - An in-depth progression system in both casual and competitive formats (character levels and forced ranked system make every game you play matter, no matter how well it went) - Interesting and fitting music and atmosphere combination - A steep learning curve that promotes learning from your mistakes and evaluating yourself after every game - A great balance of being rewarded by efficient teamwork, while also not being completely subdued to failure from terrible teammates - The said progression system rewards you with ways to change up your play for every match and differentiates you from other players, even with a set meta installed on what's good and what's bad - A way for solo gameplay to not make you anxious about what your teammates do and what they think about you (mainly caused by lack of chat, and a rewarding point system for helping eachother out)  The game has all of this.  Yes, there's some flaws and bugs. Some balancing issues as well. But most people complain about things in the game that I find are not a problem to begin with; like difficulty of playing as a survivor, perks being extremely strong when you're higher leveled, lack of communication in game, lack of group matchmaking (EDIT: THEY ADDED THIS IN, and it works just fine with a few queue'ing issues but still playable) and how hard it is to rank up as a survivor.  All I need to say is that the game fits my expectations on what makes a multiplayer game fun and is one of the only multiplayer games out there that makes me play all by myself from day and night, and all of the decisions they made that many other people don't like are justified in my rightful opinion.   And most of all, it's one of those games where you spend time progressing to get new things and at the same time you will notice yourself getting better and better as you play more and more.   It's just a highly rewarding experience, and a lot of fun too.

OK. a few things first. Dead by Daylight is super hard on your nerves. I mean, jangly, shredded, shaking to the point you have to sit back for a couple minutes after you complete the match, whether you survive or not. For people who do not like Horror genres, being scared or the adrenaline spike you get after playing the most brutal game of Hide and Seek ever, you do NOT want to play this game.  Having said that.....  Holy jumping Jesus, this game is crazy CRAZY addictive. Let's start out with the game itself. You and three other survivors are on a randomly generated map, with a killer who's only purpose is to kill you by sacrificing you on a meat hook. You escape by finding five generators on the map and repairing them, which reveal the exit(s). During this time you are unable to communicate with your fellow survivors, saving pre-arranged signals developed before the match started.    Any noise you make alerts the killer and displays on his screen. ANY noise. Screw up a generator repair, he hears it. Wimpering in a closet while he's going by, he hears it. Knock a pallet down, you guessed it. The map is large and varied, so the killer may be on the other side of the map, or he might be in the cornfield with you. The only way you know for sure is the scary music with violins ramps up and your heartbeat starts getting really loud. If he gets close enough to you, you'll spot his field of vision as a red mist near the ground. Note to new players, if you can see the red glow behind you, chances are good you are hook-bait. Survivor's play in third-person mode, whilst the killer plays in first-person mode. This allows the survivors to have 360 degree vision, whilst the killer is only able to see in directly in front of him.   Now in addition to all of this, there is a Meta-game as well. Your characters may be equipped with items such as first aid kits, toolboxes, maps etc. etc. purchased with Bloodpoints (XP) or found in each match in chests littered about the sprawling map. These items give you bonus's and help you escape; however, if you are caught with one in the map and are sacrificed, you lose it permanently. Conversely, if you find an item in the map and escape with it, it is part of your inventory (until you are sacrificed with it, losing it). This makes it a double challenge on the map as you are looking for generators and items, while keeping an eye out for the killer who is probably behind you.  There are currently four survivors to choose from and three killers. It's simply amazing. The more I play, the more I want to play. Get this game. Unless you are not a horror genre fan, this game is a must buy.

Dead By Daylight is a very fun game, one of the funnest games I've played in a while. While is this game so fun you ask? Well silly, you're not supposed to ask questions nowadays. But I'll tell you why anyways.  In my opinion, there are two very important things that make this game worth playing. First of all, this game is not like any other horror game I have ever played. Almost every single horror game I've played is 'OoooOoo! Watch out! The boogeyman is out to get you!'. Now don't get me wrong, there is a villian that is out to get you. However, this game doesn't try to rub it in your face. Another thing I like about the villians you are going against is that you aren't playing against an AI, you are playing against another human being. This means they have their own tactics and ways of getting you. There is also more than one killer which consist of The Trapper, The Hillbilly, The Wraith, and The Shape. I will not talk about what makes them unique but they all have their own unique way of playing them. Now that we know how that the killers do not all act the same and that they are real people (Most of the time, sometimes you end up with bots. But those are rare and are broken now so they are free bloodpoints), we can talk about the other fun parts of the game.  The next fun part about the game is the way it instills horror into the survivor running from the killer. One of the way's it lets you know a killer is near is that it uses music that gradually increases in tensity like in movies when something bad is going to happen. I find this much more effective than jumpscares, and actually keeps me on my seat (Where as FNAF would get old fast, as when I knew they would happen it would be like someone going boo). The same goes for the person playing as the killer. While the killer doesn't have music that gets more tense when he gets close to a survivor (As that would be overpowered), he gets his own chase music when he indeed finds a survivor. There is also one more thing that I love about the survivor and the killer, their perspective. This is the first game I have ever played that switches between first and third-person depending on the situation and I think it is a great balance technique. The survivor is in third person, which lets them see the killer from other places than right in front of them. The killer is stuck in first person, making him have to constantly look for survivors and can't see multiple at the same time unless they are right in front of him.  Now, this doesn't mean the game comes without it's cons.  In my opinion, when the game first came out, it was very, very glitchy when it came to lobbies. This meant that it could take ages to get into a lobby and if it ever failed to find one it would end up making you have to ready up again. This doesn't seem to bad until you're in a survive with friends lobby where you all have to ready up again. This has been fixed though, which I am very thankful for! There is still a problem with the hosting though. Instead of having a dedicated server for the survivor and killer to connect to it relies on the killer to be the host. This means that if the host has crappy internet everyone has to deal with it. This means that you could end up going to different locations randomly during a chase (Which it is vital in such a time to stay away from the killer) and could end up causing you to be downed by the killer. Not fun. While I think this is a way to let the game last even after the game is dead and not played by many people, I would prefer the servers be hosted in a traditional way (By the games company) then when the game had it's servers shutdown switch to the method where the killer is the host.  This game also has DLC, which I consider a con most of the time. And here's why. Whenever I buy a product, I want that product to be FINISHED. Tell me, when you buy a cheeseburger, does the restaurant make you pay extra for the pickles? Well if they do you shouldn't go to that restaurant. But you get my point. However, this game is not too bad with it. It's DLC is pretty cheap, goes on sale alot of the times, and normally adds a lot of content. I would say the only DLC that I consider pay to win in this game is Michael Myers (The Shape) as he has a very easy way of downing the survivors.  TL;DR  Pros: Cool villians, great atmosphere Cons: Overpowered DLC, uses weird lobby system.

There you are, crouched down, slowly repairing a generator to make it functional again. You're aware of your surroundings and are on constant alert for the killer. Then in the silence, a faint heartbeat is heard...you know the killer is close. As the heartbeat gets louder you decide it's better to survive than be caught, so you slowly creep away to hide behind a boulder. But it was too late, the killer spotted your crouched silhouette and starts lumbering right towards you. You sprint away, not worrying about the trail you leave behind, all that matters now... is escape. You run, looking for any path that could throw him off your trail. The heartbeat is now accompanied by a anxiety inducing grinding noise...you know he's closer. You dodge around trees and hay bales, hoping he slips up. The music and heartbeat more intense than ever and now a red glow shines on your back. You know he is right behind you know. Your blood flushes from your head, and just as the killer swings their weapon, you slam a pallet down between the two of you, stunning the killer. As you hear his moans of frustration at his ruined kill, you hop through an open window and slowly crawl out into cover. You crouch in hiding, as you watch him search the area for you. He eventually give up chase and goes off to find another survivor. You crawl away, looking for the next generator to repair and hopefully make way for your escape.     If you've ever played Amnesia, then you know about the water filled hallway sequence. Dead by Daylight is that...but for the whole time...and it's awesome! This is honestly one of the best games I've played in a long time. Are there balance tweeks to be made? Yes..But every game like this has tweeks to be made. It's a constant balance that doesn't ever really end, and I think the devs are doing a great job at it. The feeling of escape or the feeling of a perfect kill is great. Being the last survivor and finally escaping through the hatch after a long cat and mouse game is also one of the big highlights of this game.  Dont let the naysayers with 'OP!' and 'It's BROKEN!' and 'UNFAIR!' throw you off... Don't get bitter, get better and get this game! Oh...and stay away from the dungeons...bad juju down there.

A good asymetrical horror game. So, what do I like about this game: -Playing as the killer and feeling so powerful -Playing as the survivor and outsmarting the killer -The Template maps being 'randomly generated' every round to give it some variety -The DLC, which is appropriately priced for the content it offers -Sound Design: gets my heart beating everytime and really gets me in the horror mood -Atmosphere: this game will make you scared when you first start out, and will still entertain those of you with weaker wills (like me)  What's not really good nor bad: -The leveling system: while grindy and abilties randomly earned, it is an enjoyable system that offers the ability to make decisions as you go through the blood web -Map Randomness: while it is logical that you shouldn't know what map you are going to get, there should be a higher chance of getting the DLC maps by default so you have more opportunities to experience them -Dev Updates: while it is great that they are trying to keep the game balanced, some of their decisions have been debateable at best -Graphics: they serve their purpose, but nothing more -Achievements: It will probably over 500 hours of grinding to 100% this game, which can be good or bad depending on how you like your game  What's bad: -Matchmaking: no dedicated servers or matchmaking system, so it is all based off host (killers) connectivity. It takes far too long to find a game because of this system, as well as ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you off in the process -Bugs: many have been fixed, but they do exist and can ruin a round for you -Ranking system: why is there only 1 matchmaking mode and it is competitive?! Honestly, it is pretty silly -Players: there will always be camping killers and weak-willed survivors that ruin rounds for you, but thats a staple in every multiplayer game now-a-days  Overall, it's worth the buy if you want to have some scary, asymetrical horror fun, especially if you have some friends who play it!! If you are too weak-willed or incredibly impatient, than I would watch some gameplays before you buy.

Is it perfect? No. Is it fun? Bloody hell yes.   This game isn't going to be for everyone. Odds are you ARE going to be helpless as a suvivor. That's the point. Survivors are suppose to be helpless against a Killer. As a suvivor you don't play to win games, you play to survive them. And as a Killer you play to do one thing and only one thing, kill. If you don't like being helpless against an unstopable Killer IF he finds you, then odds are you aren't going to like Dead by Daylight. But if you are smart. Then either the Survivors or Killer can turn the odds in their favor to make fools out of the other.  Pros- -Playing as a slasher flick killer. 3 of them with more in the works. -Being a victim of a slasher flick. Escape death with skill, maybe just dumb luck, or die in soiled pants. -4v1 gameplay that goes extra lengths to make each side stand apart from the other. -Great use of sounds for information. -RNG tile based maps. 1-2 landmarks per map will aways be in the same places, but everything else will change every game. -Games last 10 minutes on average.  Cons- -Some model bugs like rarely seeing your own hair/eyes as a Killer or some janky movement with Killers interacting with suvivors. -Balance. One Killer is weaker than the other 2. Windows close together can make near 100% safe zones for survivors depending on a few things. Some perks are rather annoying, maybe a touch OP. -Games have no timers. If someone wants to waste your time, they can if they are good enough. -No communication. It is impossible to talk to each other without 3rd party chats like Steam, Teamspeak, Skype, ect. -Making a lobby as a Killer can take up to 10 minutes to fill. Not from player counts mind you. Either another bug or a waiting list with strict 'first come, first filled' rules.  In short-  For $20 you are going to get one hell of a fun game! Just note that it might not be for everyone as not everyone can handle playing as victims who are by design made to be helpless more often than not.

It's hard to say wether this game is worth buying, so I'm going to list off some pros and cons. Pros:  -Amazingly fun to play with friends. -Unlockable loot keeps you wanting to play so you can unlock new items to use in game.  -On High settings, the game looks great, mood is nearly perfect. -Makes you rely on your senses and wits to outsmart your opponents. -Perks/Items aren't trashed in private games. There's no in between. You can't play with two of your buddies and fill the other slots with randoms. -No in game voice chat. Communication is important when playing as a survivor. I would say for me that it was worth the $20 because some of my friends own the game. I don't enjoy playing the online game mainly because I'm all alone due to the lack of communication. So after watching some guys on YouTube play this game and looking like they were having a total blast, I decided I could risk the seventeen dollar price. So I'll do a pros and cons thing first and then tell my experiences as survivors and killers.  Pros:  -Fantastic premise for a game. Four almost defenseless survivors against one bloodthirsty killer. Love it! -It's been quite some time that a game has gotten me this immersed. Like when I'm mere seconds from completeing a goal as a survivor and the killer is coming at me at full speed makes me heart pound. -Getting to slaughter a group of young adults in a brutal fashion is a blast.  Cons:  -Rampant Disconnection. My very first game had the killer disconnect and shut down the match because us survivors were already opening the exits and he hadn't even injured a single one of us. This has happened about a total of three times out of about ten games. I've noticed a few surivors on my team as well disconnect the moment they realize that we couldn't save them. Only about two times for this. From the forums this looks to be a massive loophole that helps save a players useable items and rank. Devs said they have fixed this. -It's not scary. It gets my heart beating from some close calls, but I've never been scared. I'd blame this on the 3rd person view survivors always have. Now, I almost want to give this a pass since this is first and foremost a multiplayer game, survivors need to have 3rd person to survive.  -The maps are kinda randomly made, but not enough to notice any difference. AKA, not something that should be advertised as a feature.  P.S. These are just issues I have noticed. As a killer I never had a survivor make use of a multiple windows to avoid me forever, something a lot of people have brought up. Same goes for Killer perks being useless and survivors being OP.  Now onto my little tales.  As a survivor I've had multiple close calls. Like I mentioned above, opening the gate to escape with only two seconds left until it opens and having the killer be in full site coming at me full speed. These moments are awesome. As are the times you are running for your life, with the killer right behind you. Or even hiding in a cabinet as the killer wanders by, hoping he doesn't decide to search for you. The only survivor I've played as is Dwight.  As for Killers, I've done Trapper and Hillbilly. As Trapper, it is so fun to lay a perfectly hidden trap and then watch a survivor get caught as they try to save their team. Hillbilly... well I sucked as him. Big time. All four survivors got away and I only hooked one and didn't land a single chainsaw attack. Overall you feel super powerful, knowing that the survivors can do barely anything to stop you.   TL:DR: From my experience, this game has been a blast. It's intense as a survivor and brutally fun as a killer. For me the sheer amount of fun I've gotten from my short experience is enough to make me feel safe in my purchase.

Without doing much in-debt analysis, I'll just list a few pros and cons that I think a new player will likely experience:  Pros:  Atmosphere: for your first hundred or so hours, as long as nothing from reality breaks your immersion, you're very likely going to get immersed in the game and it will feel awesome. Whether you go on a calculated hunt or tense repair mission, you're really going to feel it well. And even if immersion breaks, for example, after a very long playtime of several hundred hours, the tension and gameplay fun remains.  Continuous development: it's not a free-access half-baked game, really, but game grows and new content is being added, including new survivors and killers, balancing patches and much more. I find it a big plus because the game is not stagnant and you're going to see new content (which, so far was not lacking).  Simple, but tricky: relatively simple ruleset for a match in general, yet so many things to master. There are lots of small details during gameplay that can improve you as a player, many different tactical methods to behave in certain situations. Many choices, which have to be done real-time and some options aren't all that obvious. And, because you're constantly playing against real people, your ability to quickly read other people and behave accordingly is also trained well here.  Fun to play with friends: game definetely not requires you playing in a party, but if you got someone with whom you can voice chat and play this game - it's going to be some pretty fun time. If you're a survivor with no friends in lobby, you may not be in the most favorable conditions, but if you're a lone killer then you're definetely doing it right.  Cons: Relatively poor optimisation and possible crashes: although runs relatively good on my very 'mediocre' PC, if you're used to 60 FPS on weak PC then you're going to get disappointed. Some people speak about crashes and stuff, but as long as I unplug my Xbox 360 controller from my PC I am not crashing at all (although if I don't, then, sometimes I actually do crash my game). If you got some good hardware out there and you know how to use it, though, then you're certainly fine with this game.  Salty community: if you're afraid of being judged by random people and you can't properly escape those situations - then beware, because this game attracts many salty individuals who can tell you stuff in post-match chat. It's not a bad side for me, because I simply don't care, but some new people may and for that reason I'm listing it in here.    All in all, I definetely recommend this game, especially for the price it has been listed on Steam. Dead by Daylight gave me a lot of experience and good times, and I'm sure there's much more to come.

It's a game with a lot of potential. But you should treat it like a Beta version. It still has a lot of bugs and balancing issues. From glitched out items, to vastly underpowered perks. I myself am rank 1 in both killer and survivor and I can say without any doubt that ranking up with killer is child's play compared to ranking up as a survivor. You really need to mess up as a killer to drop in rank.  Furthermore the grind to level up is very long, also because of perks that are useless. There are some perks so useless that when you would combine two of them, it would still be useless (like 'this is not happening' and 'deja vu'). If you are new to the game, a camping killer will ruin your experience. Unfortunately most of them will be campers at the lower ranks, as its easier and will still reward the killer with points. Also if you're starting to play as a killer you'll be annoyed by people who use infinite loops. But you'll learn how to deal with both cases as you get better.  Then the matchmaking. You'll hear it from everyone but it's true. The matchmaking isn't just bad, it's terrible. If you want to play with friends, prepare to spent at least just as much time playing the game as waiting to finally get into a lobby. And don't expect to do something else in the meantime while you're searching for a lobby as you have to press the 'ready' button every 15 seconds.  In the end it's still a good game, eventhough it still needs a lot of work.

• What is Dead by Daylight? *Updated 12/24/2016* edits * *  o DBD is Horror game focusing on 1 v 4 asymmetrical gameplay Killer vs Survivors. While most horror games today focus too much of its scare factor on jump scares to accomplish its task DBD takes another approach gradually increasing tension. The tension brought on by the sense of your impending demise and the heart beat building intensity, or for killers the sound of completed generators which signals that the amount of time you have left to sacrifice the survivors is almost up. Or sneaky survivors which you have a hard time tracking down. DBD puts 4 survivors against a killer who must repair five generators and work as a team before they scarified by meat hook to the entity.  • The Good:  o I love this game, and would recommend you to give it a try.  o Randomly generated maps and layout o As of 9/28/16 the game IS NOT a jam packed DLC cash cow with micro transactions *Every DLC except for the nurse you would have to pay for*  o Feeling of a 80s horror movie where at any moment the killer could be right over your shoulder.  o The soundtrack and heartbeats as the killer grows nearer always puts you at a state of unease and is spot on (even with ~200 hours in it still feels uneasy) *survivors are no longer scared of the killer bc of their perks*  o Even though Evolve (Original Not Stage 2) and this game focus on asymmetrical gameplay do not compare them; that would not be doing this game justice.  o The problem of unbalanced matchmaking *hasnt been fixed* o Fairly low $20 price tag o Devs seem very passionate about their project so the game should have frequent updates, support, and future content.   • The Bad:  o The Bugs: At launch the game was very buggy but with frequent updates the game feels a bit smoother, but you will encounter some bugs, like all games. *Still many bugs months later*  o The game favors survivors most killers are no longer viable against survivor perks and try hard survive with friends*  o Infinites and campers *the problem now is survivors the meta builds desisive strike / self care / adrenaline / sabotage* makes most veteran survivors unkillable*  o Unsure of the Devs direction on future DLC plans *all payed*  o Getting out of rank 20 hell (~ 16 – 20) can be a nightmare bc of inexperienced survivors o Laggy killers need for dedicated servers *still*  Simply type 1 repeatedly in the lobby chat to test for lag.  o Every perk on both sides should feel as a viable option to match a certain playstyle but this is not the case, some perks such as iron grasps on the killer side are absolutely mandatory while others are a waste of a slot o A few killers use macro bots (depending on your outlook can be a hindrance or a quick way to farm points for both parties).  o Would like to see more emotes or proxy voice communication (restricted to a limited distance for survivors)  o Would like to see an additional game mode / focus on completing a different randomly decided objective rather than generators every game.   • Final Thoughts:  o Don’t let the number of problems that I brought up dissuade you from purchasing the game. The game is amazing and the unique dynamic between killer vs survivors and an altruistic team focused survivor group vs a selfish group that views itself as individuals that hasn’t been matched in any game that I have seen. You can read all the reviews on steam, but until you play it you will never know if a game is right for you. The game does have a few problems but what game doesn’t these days. Once a problem is found the devs usually get taken care of in a timely manner. I would like to see more item diversity on the survivor’s side. As of today I would rate DBD an 8/10 it has a few problems but does several new things for gaming and does them quite well.   • TIPS: Your focus while playing shouldn’t be to kill everyone or simply survive you must entertain the ominous prescience known as the entity in several ways if you wish to rank up, completing objectives surviving, helping teammates etc. If you face camp survivors on the hook not only does it take away from the overall fun for survivors,but you don’t get nearly as many points for chasing the survivors usually results in a derank.  • Learn how to hide, and remain calm, the killer can only see your tracks when you run so use this to your advantage.  • Repairing the generators to 99% and not completing it is a strong option for survivors, killers have more generators to patrol meaning that they are less likely to find you.  • Survivors can now crouch past and crouch next to crows without setting them off. This is a new hiding option for survivors that is quite effective, most killers even the more experienced ones will look for alerted crows to see if a survivor has been in the area and will not walk near them in fear of setting them off themselves.  • At the start of the trail look for a hook first, each killer has their own hook allowing you to identify the killer and lets you prepare a strategy against that killer, also watch you should watch out for.  . Killers also have their own distinct sound grunts, chainsaw, bells, claps of a trap, shrieks etcs to let you know which killer it is.  • Also at the start of the trail try to get a sense of where the killer is before starting a gen, a generator with little to no progress is often an indicator that a survivor is near.  • Learn how to do the quick time skill checks and master getting great skill checks.  o Failing the skill checks not only slows down the time it takes for healing sabotaging a repairing but it also alerts the killer to you location which could compromise a whole team.  • If you are on the fence about purchasing the game I would say go ahead and try it out. I hope the tips that I provided will allow you to get out of survivor hell and rank high in no time.
