Dead by Daylight is a team horror/survival game with unique gameplay, great atmosphere, and challenging game mechanics that don't fail to impress.  The Good - Very Unique gameplay that takes a lot of skill and patience to learn, let alone master - Lots of fun playing both the survivor and the killer once you've figured out some strats - Perks and items add a lot of new challenges and variations in gameplay strats for both killer and survivor - Atmosphere is great, sound and visuals do a good job at keeping you on edge, especially as the survivor - Very unique feel to the team based gameplay, group doesn't live or die as a team, individual actions are important - Devs seem to be still be working on the game and improving it - Music is really good, and does a lot to enhance the feel of the game - Very entertaining to watch - Every action you take is important, and every decision you make matters. It's very easy to die in this game so planning and strategy are hallmarks - Game is unforgiving and not noob friendly, there is a high barrier to entry that must be overcome to 'git gud'  The Bad - Game is unforgiving and not noob friendly, there is a high barrier to entry that must be overcome to 'git gud' - Individualistic teamplay means that teamates will often abandon you if things go south - Killers camping hooks, while a valid strategy, ruins the fun a bit - Queuetimes can be really bad if not enough killers or survivors are playing - Bloodweb leveling feels a bit pointless, a better leveling and perk system might help this game out - Lots of grind to obtain perks, meaning it will be a while before you get to experiment with different builds - Some perks are just terrible compared to others, the perks aren't well balanced  The Ugly - The queue process is terrible. If you don't get into the game, the system will kick you out and make you queue up again. Queue should not have to be entered multiple times, the player should remain in the queue until he or she finds a game. - Easy ways to exploit the blood system in multiplayer - No blood given for playing with friends as the killer. (And while I realize that allowing this would allow some serious exploits, they could have given a seperate bloodpool for offline play so you and your friends can still play together and level up in a different manner.)  Overall, I think this is a great game, but certainly not for everyone. I'd recommend watching some videos before you get it, just to make sure it boasts the type of gameplay you're looking for. Below is a video as a survivor, and you can find plently more videos on my YouTube page if you'd like to learn more.          YouTube™ Video:  The Jukes are Real

This game is really fun being both survivor/killer. However it seems that the Killer is host considering they are creating the lobby which leaves half the time if not more, survivors are lagging and at a disadvantage for rubberbanding right back to the killer. The matchmaking is kind of bugged where you'd click join lobby and it'll do nothing but put you back to that same screen prompting you to join lobby, sometimes happens over and over. Can't play with friends in public matches but for obvious reasons, i.e. boosting. However I do think that friends should at least be able to join as survivors. I've also experienced a 10 min loading screen upon entering a match where 3 ended up quitting and left me and the Killer to play. Despite the few cons I seem to have talked about, this game is fairly new so I think putting out those cons, devs may get an idea on the sorts of issues/problems the game has.   Now that the cons are out of the way, let me explain the fun facts: This game pits 4 survivors against 1 killer where you need to activate generators to open gates to escape, the killer is obviously to prevent that from happening. There are 4 different characters for survivor that have special perks that you can purchase via earning credits playing online. Same goes with the Killer but there are only 3 types of Killers which depends on your playstyle. You can also earn items that can help you in the match as well as add on's that are for that particular item. You also earn offerings that you choose before a match that will burn to apply to the match you're about to play, these offerings can be used as an advantage and also help earn you more credits. The ranking system is pretty solid where you level up your character and then you have your survivor/killer rank that you earn by actually doing the objective consistently in each category. That's all I can think of now so I'll stop here.   I give this game a 8/10 for me personally. These bugs aren't exactly gamebreaking besides the lag but that's a norm. With a few patches/updates and possibly better connection between hosts/survivors this game would be less frustrating. All in all, it's an easily enjoyable game for $20.

What I like: - Gameplay is very fun - Intense as a survivor - Statisfying as a Killer  What I don't like: - Some bugs will get you stuck so that you might have to disconnect - There are plenty of bugs  As stated above it has many bugs, BUT it is one of the games that are very funny to play so that you forget about most of the bugs. As a survivor it's a very intense experience to try to escape and as a killer it is really statisfying if you finally catch the last survivor and hook them.

Ever watch a horror movie, and yell at the characters- 'NO! Don't go in there!' Or 'It's a trap!' Or 'leave him, save yourself you idiot!' Well, now you have to make your own decisions in that very situation.  This game is like a Texas Chainsaw Massacre simulator. If you are a horror fan, such as myself, I highly recommend this game. It is incredibly atmospheric, intense, and full of dread. Playing as a survivor or as the killer are both fun, but there is a certain primitive thrill that I get from hunting people down and instilling fear in their souls with the revv of my chainsaw!  Each map, while all having a similar feel and similar props, feels unique and very horror-movie-esque (eg- cornfields, abandoned farms, etc). The game is surprisingly balanced I feel. This game isn't without problems, like matchmaking and the graphics being mediocre, but it doesn't take away from it's charm or the fun.  I recommend this game, definitely worth the price :D Especially for horror fans.

TL:DR This game is a bug filled, enjoyable mess which is only worth the full price if you have friends to play with   This is, at the moment, not a very well made game. But it IS hella fun, and that's what it sets out to be. To me, friends are crucial to enjoying this game to its full potential, it's quite fun without them but playing with friends is the real draw here. Some genuinely nailbiting and hilarious experiences come out of this game and it is genuinely just damn good fun.   The reason I say the game is not well made is that at the stage it's at right now, at August 2016, there are so many bugs, exploits, annoying mechanics and mechanics which are simply not used. Lockers are a good example. See anyone play this game even remotely seriously and they will almost never get in a locker. This eliminates an entire game mechanic not due to it being a bad idea, but just terrible execution (heh). The gameplay is at it's core repetivive with differing maps and killers only giving so much variation.   Yet there's something uniquely compelling about this game which keeps me coming back. Even as a high ranked survivor who rarely gets straight out terrified or jumpscared anymore, I have never played a game where I am so consistently on edge, 8/10 games will leave me shaking and my hands sweaty, even if I wouldn't say I was exactly 'scared'. The rush when you manage to outjuke a killer you know is quite good, the tension as you hide in wait to save your dying teammate, knowing if you're spotted its the end for them... it's engaging and compelling in a way I've almost never experienced.

Alright. First, check how many hours I've had in this game. That alone should be saying something. (I was job hunting and had plenty of time, alas, those days are over)  I could write a 10 page review on this marvelous masterpiece but I will keep it short and sweet:  This is why you NEED to buy Dead by Daylight. Best 18-20 bucks I've spent in AWHILE. As a lifelong gamer, I really can say this is a top 10 favorite.  The pros + + The music and sound effects alone make the experience literally get your heart beating faster. Hell, I think it even boosts your metabolism because of how on-edge you can become. + The game looks pretty cool. I like the style of landcape etc. The maps they have now, 3 main areas with smaller sub areas, are incredible as they are now, but there are still updates and new maps in the future. I've played easily over 100 matches, and in 3 maps, I can say with confidence that it has NOT gotten old. I'm really impressed, as being someone who plays everything from Dark Souls to Elder Scrolls to Fallout. + If you are like me and loved hide and seek and tag when you were a kid and also now, you'll love this, because basically this is a 'grown up' version of that game. + The team aspect is excellent. Banding together makes repairing, healing, and basically ensuring your survival a lot easier, and it doesn't feel poorly done or forced. I usually like working alone, but this game really makes the working with others aspect appealing. + The items/loadout works very well. Plenty of offerings to put forward, and the items available are straight to the point. + The stealth aspect and hiding behind objects etc. works nearly flawlessly, and the feeling you get when the killer runs RIGHT BY you is unparalleled. + The multiplayer aspect, plus the ability to play with friends, makes it that much more entertaining.  Negatives - - Several glitches even in the introductory part of the game while you are waiting in the lobby. That one can be overcome, but then there's some really frustrating ones in game, especially if the killer's internet is ♥♥♥♥♥♥, because you rubber band all over, or it's choppy and there's lag delays. - Although I love the 3 maps, I would definitely say more maps would definitely not be out of the question.  I'd love to answer any Qs you may have, as I almost literally know this game inside out!

First actual review for a game... I have to say this is an amazing game! Ignore the buthurt ones who complain about the game 'not being patched immediately.' It has been out for only ONE month! The Devs are on twitch occasionally announcing whats to come in the next patches, responding to the fans and sharing what they plan to do in the future of the game.. Also posting many announcements and notes on the games official Twitter page. The Devs are people too so take it easy.  All in all i bought this game for a WHOLE $17.99 USD which is NOTHING IMO (A mid/low class income guy) Heres a simple breakdown Its got four survivor choices who all have unique perks you unlock as you level them and greatly benifit you and your team. Three killers (Bound to be more... hopefully soon :D ) with the same setup (unique perks that benefit greatly)... one killer hosts a lobby and waits for four survivors to join and ready their loadout (tools, attachments, offerings, perks etc...) while the killer waits for them to ready up he can see the opposing players classes, levels, ranks and prestige lvl if aquired to know what hes up against and pick his killer accordingly. The survivors however cannot see anything info about the killer aside from his offerings until they encounter him his hooks or his weapon noises in game. Once the game begins the survivors have a goal to repair five of i think eight randomly spawned Generators which power up two randomly spawned escape doors which the survivors use to win/escape.  Now the RANKING SYSTEM: The survivors have four point categories that gather their in game score. 1. Objective - Generators/looting chests/ opening escape doors. 2. Survival - Escaping/ struggling while in the final stage of being on the hook. 3. Altruism - Healing self/allies, saving allies from hooks reuniting with split up allies. 4. Boldness - Running from the killer, escaping the killer, sabotaging killers hooks, stunning killer being a ballsy mother ♥♥♥♥er.  The ranking system requires survivors to gain a minimum of 10k points throughout these categories for one pip and 20k points for 2 pips (pip= level towards next rank). Each category maxes at 5k points towards your rank while the remaining points in the maxed category are just extras for leveling.   For example you need either 5k points in only two categories or 2.5k in each and so on to level atleast once towards the next rank. so essentially you can help teamates, do very few or NO objectives (Pls do objs though), and kite the ♥♥♥♥ out of the killer and end up dying in the end and STILL RANK UP! I strongly disagree that the ranking system is as broken as half the other reviews for this game say.  Anyways im getting to into this review for how little i do this xD. Look up the killer if you're more interested.   I highly suggest you purchase this game.  ...Sincerely a happy customer.

This is one of the most well balanced games I have seen to date. The game mechanics are simple to understand but hard to master. There is no wrong or right way to play this game but as you get better you realize that this game uses orbital mechanics when hunting and trying to get the generators. Distance of generators and how fast you move determine how well you progress. There are a few glitches and occasional graphics driver crash I have experienced but it rarely happens and overall the bugs are minimal. If the game resets for some reason it means the cloud server is out of sync. Re start the game and you will have all your stuff back, had this happen once or twice but usually it works fine. Would love more content, and possibly bigger teams in the future. The game really keeps you on your toes, you have to pay attention to your environment and focus. The higher you are ranked the more challenging the game becomes. Match making is decent but could use improvement. If you want tutorials go watch twich streamers for some great tips and see what makes a great killer / survivor. Whats also fascinating is how movement plays a huge role. Move fast as a survivor, running around like a maniac and you will get spotted and most likely caught by the killer. If you are the killer and slow to defend your turf, the 4 players will quickly grind down their generators and you are going to lose. Move fast as the killer and slow and steady as a survivor. You work faster as a team, not by running around by yourself and remember to have fun! Looking forward to more updates and new content!

Do you like killing teen agers? How about running away from pysco hillbillies with chainsaws? This might just be the game for you. Although, if you like doing either of those things in the company of friends... well you better have atleast 4 other friends with 20 bucks in their pockets.  TLDR: Good game, would recomend if you like to play solo  The week leading up to the launch of this title, I was very excited. Watching a multitude of streamers play this game with their friends made me wish I could do the same. The hype was real. When the game went live a friend of mine and I bought this game anxious to cower in fear at the likes of machette clad macocists. We then spent about 20 minutes trying to figure out how to play together. Surely there was an 'invite a friend' option we were over looking. After hosting and rehosting lobbies we discovered no such option exsists... What a let down! Dead By Daylight seems like the perfect platform to have a real horror shared-experience with friends but the only way to accomplish this is in a private game. To me, this seems like a huge over sight.   Now, understandably, I can see the developers side of this decision. Sure, playing this game as a survivor with a friend could lead to some already unbalanced game play, however I think that the whole soul of this game revolves around surviving as a group and what better way to experience that than with a friend. In my opinion if the developers were worried about competetive balance, they should have just made the match making system allow friends and then work on developing a more competetive game mode in the future.  Rant aside, let's talk about the game. Overall i really enjoy the game. The ambianceis perfect. The maps are creepy, the character modles are pretty terrifying and the mechanics are pretty solid. The feeling you get as a survivor being chased through a cornfield by a psycotic chainsaw massacre-ist is second to none. Likewise, hunting survivors as a nearly invisible wraith is awesome. Sure there are some balance issues that are being addressed, that is fine. I am happy that the developers are quick to patch this title.  Dead By Daylight is certainly worth the money with one caveat: I hope you like playing by yourself! I, however, do not and will probably not be playing this game too much until i can actually match make with my friends or somehow convince more of my friends to make the purchase.

Here's the thing about Dead By Daylight. It's broken as hell and the devs don't seem to know what the hell they're doing half the time.  And that's perfectly okay.  Dead by Daylight is a very fun game to play, solo or otherwise. The pure adrenaline of running away from the killer is something quite extraordinary. Learning all the different ways to juke the killer is something to behold as it will take hours to get right. But once you do, it's incredibly satisfying.  The current gripe the community has with the game (v1.2.1) is that the new killer, Michael Myers, is incredibly OP. This is not the case. He came out approximately 15 hours before posting this review and already the community is whining about the new killer.   If there's anything to take from that is that the community for this game can sometimes be sub-par due to them being really picky about how the game plays and are impatient about learning how to play against a killer who changes the way you play just a bit.  Another gripe the community has is that the  Halloween  DLC makes the game Play to Win. Once again, this is not the case. Yes, the DLC is $7 and includes a killer and survivor. But that doesn't mean you have to pay to get them. You can unlock the killer and survivor in game, but you cannot level them up. Yes it does suck that it's behind a paywall to get any big use out of them but that isn't pay to win, it's just inconvinient.   Overall, Dead by Daylight is an incredibly fun game that can keep you entertained for hours with its 'one more game' mentality. I highly recommend at least giving it a try, regardless of what the community says.

I RECOMMEND THIS GAME COMPLETELY - BUT PLEASE READ  Pros  It's a fun game, not so much as scary but tense. You can choose to save or abandon people which is kinda great, it brings out the monster in all of us lol. Each map has random generator spawns which can give advantage to the player, and you can also be awarded 'Offerings' which can be used to alter the map and it's surroundings to either help the Killer or the player.   Cons  There is no party system yet(although I hear it is their top priority), so you can either go solo for a while until this comes out, or you can try and join the same game as your friends(easy but can take a anywhere between 1-15 mins). ALTHOUGH you CAN play a private match with your friends however no XP is rewarded, as can be expected. Also the Killers are great, however I don't like the idea of the wraith, the fact that he can go invisible is kinda OP(however the player is alerted when he goes invisible by a bell tolling and he cannot interact or attack when invisible, which kinda makes up for it) but overall I think the character itself is a little OP. Also - and I think alot of people would agree, when you are hung up on a hook, most killers, if not ALL, will just camp the hook, which in my opinion is kinda bad because it's basically setting you up for a GG, although when the killer camps the hook it allows for everyone else to fix generators and escape, thus making a 'loss' on the killers part.   Overall  Is a great game and is worth its money, you could play hours on end without getting bored as each map variant offers great advantages and disadvantages to killer and player alike - You will NEVER always win at this game, teamwork is KEY, however you could pull a sneaky Shane on Otis from TWD and escape alone :D. However a small tweaking for friends to connect and play with each other is much needed, and personally I feel the Wraith Killer could be minorly tweaked.

this game, played well, plays like a horror movie feels. It's a solid game where the tension is enormous for survivors and the worst part of sadism blooms for the killers. 10/10. Very Active Developers, Weekly streams explaining what's going on in the office and a steady stream of updates mean this game is getting stronger all the time.  Pros: Intense 4v1 action where the constant fear of a remorseless killer pushes to you do everything in your power to escape, genious point system that incentivises the gameplay style that makes the game the most engaging it can be. wide variety of killers and maps keeps the game interesting. Thoughts from the Free Weekend:  I've had this on my wishlist for a while - I've liked the 4v1 style of games for a while, and this caught my interest. How exactly would you survive against an unstoppable serial killer? Turns out, not too great, but I'm a first-rate psychopath. Go figure. There were a few problems with the game that made it hard to get right now: First, the matchmaking issue - yeah, I know. It was addressed pretty quickly, but to go into a free weekend with a bug like that is a little unproffessional. I also had a real issue with how the matchmaking could be a complete crapshoot - sometimes, you'd have a match against 4 complete newbs like myself, the next you'd be pitted against level 40-somethings with full rare perks. IN those cases, you kinda feel like you have to resort to camping the hooks to make sure you get them, which feels more than a bit unsporting. My other big gripe of the weekend was the fact that the new DLC - with the Nurse and the new survivor - weren't open to weekenders. While I can't say the Nurse would've appealed ( I was more Trapper than anything else), it would've been handy to have a few games as her to work out how she works. Every time i decided to dip a toe into the survivors team, someone playing Nurse managed to get me on a hook within a few minutes. If I knew how her damn teleport worked, it might've helped. A few minor glitches and bugs - at one point, I took a swing at a player and ended up teleported across the map. There's also the tendency for some to just constantly hurdle over the same damn barricade - mebbe a fatigue thing could be brought in to slow them down if it's done too frequently? In its current state, I think the game needs a lot of work. The basic idea is fantastic, and once matches get going they can get pretty tense, even if playing the killer - trying to second guess your victims moves, figure out where they are and scare the everloving crap out of them, is pretty fun. As it is, it's staying on the wishlist - I'll come back to it further down the line, and see how it improves.

A simple game which requires survivors to outsmart a lone killer by using stealth and teamwork. Many people complain about the game's balance, but those are usually from low level (noob) players who unfortunately have been pitted against a high level/rank player. Some folks just get so aggravated when they lose, that they lose their minds and complain to the devs.  Those that complain that the killer is overpowered probably have never watched a horror/slasher film before, which is obviously what this game is inspired by. The killers in those movies could be considered overpowered too, so keeping that theme is spot on. BUT it doesn't mean that the survivors don't stand a chance. It just means that they need to play smarter, using the environment to their advantage.  So does the game have flaws that need to be addressed? Sure, but I'm talking about glitches, bugs, and matchmaking. Not game balancing, which isn't particularly a problem.

A fun game that you will find wastes a few hours of your day. The gameplay is fun, if not slightly repetitive, from both killer/survivor. High replayability, given it's competitive multiplayer. However, both survivor and killer can be frustrating to play. This is *for the most part* because of a mix of bugs/exploits (see the pages of random reports on the community discussions page for specifics) that can ruin a game often enough to be annoying. The reason this does not make this review negative is because I find the game fun to play!   The devs are hardworking and listen to their community and are actively fixing the game's problems. When the game works right, it works extremely well. When it doesn't, it's either very frustrating or very humorous. So, if you enjoy 4v1 multiplayer within a horror environment and are willing to support the devs through a somewhat-rocky launch, by all means, pick this game up and join the mass murdering fun! Many people are posting negative reveiws about this game because of numerous nitpicky complaints that really don't affect gameplay often enough to ruin the experience.   As an example, at the very beginning of the game's launch many people posted negatives because friend-to-friend multiplayer wasn't exsistent. This was a bad move by the devs, but it was deliberate. It was deliberate because it would shift the balance of the game towards the well-coordinated teams. Though the devs openly said this, the community didn't care. So, it was implemented early with barebones funcionality because of the community's impatience. Now what do the reviews say? That it's broken and makes it too hard for killers to play. See a problem there? Again, I will repeat, if you like this genre of game and are even slightly interested and don't mind the once-in-a-while bug that are indeed being fixed as this review is being written: don't be turned away by some of the whiny negatives, this game is worth it!

A very good game concept. Game mechanics are balanced overall. A great game to play with friends. However the game isn't really ready from my point of view. There are a lot of bugs that ruin gameplay such as, attempting to attack a survivor who is repairing a generator and instead glitching outside the map, getting stuck in a barricade ect. Additionally the ranking system takes place in any and all games you play. So any glitches will have an impact on your rank. Also, since the ranking system is active in every game you play, you can't play a 'casual game' unless you don't care about online rank. It's worth noting that the killer can see the infomation of the survivors, and the surivors can't see any infomation on the killer (I personally like this mechanic because it creates more terror, as the survivors don't know anything about the killer but the killer knows a lot about the survivors). The only problem with this is that Killers (game hosts) aren't punished for jumping matches. People often do this if they think they might lose the game. The game can take a while to pick up because the tutorial system is limited to 6 short videos. A single player option, and the option to play in either a ranked match or a casual one would improve the game. The matching making is not good enough. It can be very difficult to get into a game partly due to the reason stated 5 lines above. Overall I would say that the game is a brilliant concept, with a brilliant atmosphere, but many interface flaws. Only buy if you are prepared to deal with these issues

A survivor can sacrifice their teamate to save themselves, or risk their own life to help the teamate and gain more points. Killers can stay near the body on the hook, which guarentees that person will die, but the rest of the survivors can get generators working quicker, or the killer can run around looking for another survivor to kill, but risk letting the hooked survivor be saved. I can't host a match as killer and invite my friend (but also have randoms join, it only allows for private game, though that means 1v1). There's not that many bugs. Might find one once a week.  The survive with friends mode has been added, as promised, although that itself is going to make people angry too.  I don't really care about matchmaking. Unless your teammates are in the single digit ranks, they're pretty killable like the rest of us. If you have a good killer, he'll just have some more common sense than the average dunce.  The developers are constantly in a state of balancing the game, trying to please both sides of the game (Killers vs Survivors) which will never be at ease due to both sides wanting the game in their favor. Any issues that cause major imbalance usually get fixed quickly.  The whole 'finding game' issue is a very minor inconvenience. Oh gee, I have to press the button four times instead of once. Not a issue that will drag out the process more than five seconds.  Infinite jukes have been fixed. As reward for fixing it, the developers were greeted with hate. (fixing the issue tipped the balance back in the killer's favor)  If you really care about a rank then you may have issue with the ranking system, as it does not promote winning quickly, but rather playing like the people in horror films, which is an issue when your killer/survivor is a tryhard. (Think dramatic chase scenes and the survivor to narrowly escape, only for the killer to pop back in).  The insta-killer offerings are lame, but I've maybe been killed by them about 2-3 times in the 81 hours of gameplay that I've played, with each match being about ten minutes.  People complain about hook-camping, which is one of the few things that actually is common. Despite there being obvious disadvantages to doing this, people continue to do it. I don't really know how I would fix it, so I can't blame the development team for not fixing it either. They're sort of iffy on the issue, since I've seen them both say that it is a valid strategy, but they seem to frown upon it from judging how they talk about it.  About one in every ten games I will come across lag. It's worth noting that if you really despise it, then you will need to take that into consideration when you decide on buying the game. Due to the game being built upon a peer-to-peer system, you will have to hope that the killer is not someone who doesnt realize how bad their internet is.  A way to test whether someone has bad internet is by typing in pre-game chat and seeing the delay. It isn't a fool-proof method if the lag isn't so bad that it will delay chat but is bad enough to show up in-game, but it helps an unfixable issue.  The way of progressing through the game is through an RNG system, with each level having exactly one perk (random) and other random items which their rarity depends on your level. I have no issue with it, but due to RNG being random, someone is getting the short end of the stick and isn't happy about it.   That's all the major complaints I can think of. If you like the game and really like the gameplay, then these issues will not stop you from playing the game.

Excellent concept, spot-on gameplay that's easy to learn, nice graphics, and fun maps... all ruined by horrible matchmaking (you can't play with one or two friends - you need five whole people, or you're forced to play with an entire team of randoms), and a complete lack of in-game communication (a co-op game without in-game commuinication... great idea!). If they fix the matchmaking and add in-game communication between survivors, I will change my review.  Edit to add: weeks later and my negative recommendation still stands. The matchmaking is horrible (it takes several minutes just to find a game), it does not match you with people like your rank (nothing quite like being a low-level survivor matched with a top-ranked killer, and vice-versa), you cannot play with your friends (the game simply does not allow it to work), there are several game-breaking issues (such as ring-around-the-rosies created by chokepoints), and the latency on servers is caused by the poor P2P choice. To cherry on top is that anyone who voices these legitimate complaints to the community are met with verbal abuse about how they should just 'git gud.'  Final edit: they fixed the matchmatching, ended the problem of people leaving all the time by hiding levels and ranks from other players, and solved a lot of the match dropping. Not to mention that you are able to play with friends now - it finally works. I'm a happy camper now.

When I got this game, I was pretty excited. One of the coolest concepts I have ever seen, sorta like a mature L4D promising actual adrenaline and the thrill of an invincible murderer. This was also like Amnesia where survivors' hopes in escaping is poisoned with how powerful the killer is.  Reality was actually how I thought it would be. There were many chases and scenes, period of times where my (real-life) heart beat as fast avatar's in the game.  I recommend this game because despite the bugs and the current unbalanced state, it's still damn fun.    Now, my warning.   It IS buggy. The game is like a really handsome/sexy individual you wanna date. Only thing is he or she has like an IQ of 80. Perhaps you are just gunning for the looks department here, so I guess you might want to date him or her anyway.  Dead by Daylight is like that. There are going to be some of you looking for a fully optimised game like Overwatch. Even if the game has a cool concept, maybe you ain't gonna have fun as long as the game is still buggy.     That's totally fine.    For people who haven't yet BOUGHT the game, I am just gonna list the current MAJOR bugs/annoyance. I hope it will help in making your decision.      PROS   It's sorta like a multiplayer Amnesia. You can't fight off the killer so you escape, you hide. This concept of being in a hopeless horror game IS ♥♥♥♥ING FUN. The thrill is amazing. All the dopamine and adrenaline like a drug that gets me high. And you live and die- then right to the next game where you can do it again. The perks you can get(passive abilities) also really changes the game so it gets really fun when you get them. You feel the significance of it helping you, really aiding and changing YOUR STYLE of escaping the killer.  You wanna be a team helping aura survivor? Sure. Someone that can sabotaged the killer's stuff? Why not? How about someone more individualistic. You ain't gonna help anyone so your perks are just for you to move faster and quieter? Hell yeah. There are many styles and perks. It's fun to actually experiment with them.   Have the killer caught someone? You have to make a choice now- do you want to risk your live saving the nimcompoop or just try selfishly by yourself to make an escape? It's your life, your choice. And you will be scared while making that choice.        CONS    It's damn buggy. Some minor, some major. You know how you click a button ONCE in other games to queue? Then you sit back, relax and wait till you enter a game? Ain't like that here. You gotta click it a couple of times. It will still only take you a couple of clicks- but there might be time periods where you gotta click more. So yeah- you click to queue. And then after awhile, you might have to CLICK again. And again.      There are exploits to be used- I guess this is a subset of buggyness but I am just gonna explain as another point. You can still win as survivors and killers but there ARE exploits. To me, I feel they ain't being abused that much so it's still alright. Mods are also trying to fix them every patch- and since the game came out, it's WAAAY better. Still, if you hate the very concept and don't have much tolerance for them then yeah okay- maaaaaybe not your thing.     Might feel the game is a tad unbalanced. As every patch nerfs and buffs the killers and survivors, there is a meta. Where a certain killer/survivor is OP and everyone uses them. Yeah this exist. But honestly, most games have this 'meta-complain'.     In conclusion, I still advise you guys to get it. The raw fun I get is too damn great. And I am sure the game will improve into a more optimised state(give the mods some time- they are a pretty small studio).

Pros: * Very simple and fun game design. It's pretty easy to learn but very hard to master. * Addictive. There is a strange feeling where you'll want to play more even when things are not going to well.  * Bloodpoints/Bloodweb. The rewarding system is very good. You get rewarded based on your actions, not matter the game result. You can lose and still be nicely rewarded, so you are not so dependent on your team to have a good result. Of course, winning is always better. * It will take you some time until you have played through all content so the value for the price of the game is pretty good. * This game is even better with friends. If you have no friends, you can always go killer and slaughter everyone.  Cons: * No dedicated servers. The hosting is done by the killer. This creates lag and a lot of problems joinnig a game. This also creates a feeling of distrust since killer can abuse the fact that he is the server. * Bad matchmaking. Matchmaking is kinda random. Be ready to learn how to play the game against seasonal players in your first matches, the game makes a very bad job trying to pair players of equal level of experience/skill, which can be very frustrating in the beginning.  It's really up to you to decide if the pros overcome the cons. I guess it will depend on each person.

Not enough adolescent teen sacrifices lately. This game makes up for it. Concept is simple. If you're a killer, track down the wimpy flesh bags. They leave tracks when they run making it easy to find them. Find them, place them on hooks. Wait for their team mates to try and rescue them. Rinse and repeat. As the survivors your job is to not die. Don't make noise, don't run around taking pictures, get the generators, hit space bar, and if you hear your character's heart beat, try not to run, hide instead. Three different killers: wraith, trapper, and hillbilly. Wraith has the ability turn invisible and move really fast, but can't attack when doing so. He's really good at finding survivors but not as good at taking them down. Trapper places bear traps to catch the survivors who enjoy exploiting the fact that survivors can vault windows easier than the killer, or to protect survivors who are being sacrificed. Hillbilly is my fave :). Rev up dat chainsaw and scare survivors out of hiding or use it instead of his primary weapon when chasing down survivors for a 1 hit knockdown. Survivors have a lot of freedom in how they want to play. Knock down hooks with the toolkit to make it harder for the killer to make a sacrifice, heal themselves or team mates with first aid kits, or distract the killer so that another survivor may escape or get a generator running. My biggest problem is too many quitters. Lots of people leave the match because they don't like playing anymore the moment they are caught or sacrificed by the killer. Use that time to watch your team mates and see what they do right or wrong. You can play with friends but only in private matches. This is fine considering unlockables don't really offer much of an advantage but annoying when you realize how cliche random survivors can be. You got the overly confident who keeps vaulting windows and t bagging (funny when you're a trapper though). The saviors who focus only trying to get everyone out alive (doesn't happen), the stupid every worst horror movie actor who's the first to get caught, gets saved, watches her savior get caught, flees, and gets caught again (usually the players who quit early), and the every man for himself guy who goes for a few generators and then waits for everyone else to die so that he can use the escape hatch.

Dead by Daylight is an easy game; there are not a lot of difficult game mechanics. The (four) survivors have to fix generators and the killers has to - obviously - kill them. This is one of the few games that didn't start to bore me after playing it for a week - and that says something. However, you're not rewarded for playing as a team. When the first survivor is hanged on a hook, the killer usually camps, making it harder for you to win. Best strategy: hide until the first survivor hangs, fix all the generators and escape.  PROS - Easy to pick up. - It never gets boring.  CONS - Camping killers. - It sometimes feels like an early access game. (Game can crash, minor bugs and glitches)

Great game, well worth the mere $20 even if you can't quick play with friends. I agree with the idea that having a premade survivor group would put a massive disadvantage to the killer. The immersion of the game is ruined. Instead of being a rag tag group of survivors, you become a telepathic strategic machine, capable of communicating with each other across the map without the killer being able to hear your discord chat. If premade groups become a thing in quick play, the killers will have to be massively buffed.  3 killers allows 3 very different flavors of hunting the survivors. The trapper caters towards strategic players, placing traps to cut off juke points and escapes. The hillbilly is the 'direct' approach, using a chain-saw charge ability to stampede towards players. The wraith (my favorite) is the mind-game killer. So many possibilties of out-thinking players, especially when you have one on a hook, waiting in the shadows and reappearing as soon as a player commits to helping his friend. Haven't played a game of this genre done this well in a long time.

As much of a buggy piece of ♥♥♥♥ this game is, it's surprisingly fun and addicting albeit repetitive. When you get used to everything, the ball starts rolling.  Starting off, the game legitimately had me scared. Not cowering-under-the-covers kind of scared, but legitimately nervous and afraid of dying and losing the match because the killer is very intimidating. Especially during moments of pressure when you're being chased down or have to force yourself to not panic in order to sneak and not give up your position, because stealth is very much so rewarded.  This game is not easy, especially when starting off as a survivor. If you're coming into the game ignorant, you're going to be making a LOT of mistakes. That's why it's good to be with friends or 'survive with friends' so that someone's there to show you the ropes. I feel a lot of newcomers jump into this clueless and get salty, which is honestly understandable. This game isn't so casual as it requires some commitment, especially with how grindy it can be with the bloodpoints system. On the contrary, the killer's part is a lot easier. Don't get me wrong, it's not baby mode, you have to at least know what you're doing or you're going to get trolled by teabagging survivors who constantly juke, stealth, and farm bloodpoints from your lack of ignorance. But with some commitment, you'll do just fine as a killer as well.  Survivor and Killer are completely different worlds, and which being more fun is all up to preference, Survivor is more difficult and focuses more on keeping you on edge, where you have to keep a level head and not give away your position. In the end, you have to be as stealthy as possible and not give yourself away unless you absolutely must have to, such as saving a friend from an impending doom. But you gotta be clever too and wary about the kind of noise you make when performing certain actions.  Killer on the other hand is easier and is all about hooking them up. You assert your dominance and gain pleasure from their panic and despair. While Killer is a walk in the park in comparison, you still have to be clever about what you do, because survivors can be just as clever. With the first person perspective, it is surprisingly easy to lose track of your prey or have mind games be played on you. When you overcome this barrier, you'll soon learn that you get the most satisfaction from not only sacrificing survivors, but playing with your food (which coincidentally is a perk too). Camping and securing your kill isn't usually a good thing to do, as hooking survivors repeatedly can net you more bloodpoints (and fun, too). When you hook someone and walk away, they will stop doing generators to help each other, which can clue you in on where they are about to go next. Even if they successfully save someone, they only have a certain amount of times they can be hooked before an instant death. It's very much possible to get lots of bloodpoints without sacrificing a single survivor, because you are moreso rewarded on the amount of actions you perform. But in the end, you would want to get multiple hooks, and if possible, kill absolutely everyone after you've grinded them out.  Now, I'm not here to tell people how to play the game, but the intention here is that you're suppose to be scared as a survivor. If you're teabagging all over the place, can you honestly call yourself scared? No. If you're discouraged from messing around and instinctively try to get out ASAP, can you call yourself at least a little bit worried? Yes. What confuses me the most is when people talk about balance and use that as their entire argument for downvoting the game. I understand that balance is very often important, but in this case, Dead by Daylight is a unique case. Yes, the killer will kill you once they find you. Yes, Michael Myers will one shot you if he keeps staring at you for long enough. But is he impossible to beat? The answer is no. Michael Myers is very strong, one of the strongest infact, but he is not OP like the Nurse once was. Once you figure him out, you'll once again learn that stealth is still very much so rewarded, because being one shotted isn't a thing when he doesn't even know where you are, right? And if he finds you, you're SUPPOSE to be scared and concerned about living or not. There shouldn't be a definitive strategy to never getting caught, such as infinitely juking or hiding. It's kind of dependent on luck. That's why the maps are randomized and never consistently the same. In a way, this games runs off of RNG or situations that are not very easy to control. If you know what to expect, that gives you a sense of security. But no, Dead by Daylight is a game where you should never feel safe and the devs try to make it so with every patch. The killers SHOULD have an advantage over the survivors, otherwise it wouldn't be a 'survivor horror' game, now would it? Now don't get me wrong, there were plenty of times where both sides had unfair advantages or just completely illogical things happening, but the devs handle it as diligently as possible.  And what's with all these people complaining about paid DLC? He's MICHAEL MYERS from Halloween. Do you honestly think the devs can profit off of a licensed franchise and legally get away with it? I feel like there's a bunch of kids these days with mob mentalities who just look at Capcom's DLC practices, then just use that as reference to start hating on all forms of DLC as if they know that the system is corrupt and that they're here to preach the truth and fight the power. Why don't you actually take a little bit of a time out of your day and learn about how corporation works?  In closing, this game is fairly new; a couple months old. It's got a long way to go, and I'm hoping that it goes somewhere within the next year or so. It'll either be dead or still kicking. I'm hoping it's kicking. Despite my hours, I felt I made this review very early. And besides, some argue that this feels like an early access game. And trust me, it sure does feel like one. I'm just hoping there's much more to come in the future. Not just new survivors, killers, and maps, but more objectives and content. I understand it might be kind of difficult to come up with new ideas since honestly, this game is a one-of-a-kind and requires a different approach. Why is this game, with as many bugs as it has, is still frequently played? Because literally no one else has made a game like it. But an exception might be Friday the 13th coming soon.

Although outside pressure probably had something to do with its release date  *cough*  before it was done  *cough* (why not closer to halloween?)  I appreciate that this game was released when it was to allow the community to shape the balance and tweaks to gameplay and allow time to grind up points for advancement. I believe this game is a lot of fun for the following reason:   YOU ARE IN A HORROR MOVIE  Previous games have used the multiplayer aspect to pit monsters versus survivors, but not quite on this level before. One can be a helpless survivor, scrambling to escape a never-ending nightmare with others they can choose to cooperate with or bait the monster with to save their own hide. You can be the killer, fast, powerful, and driven with malice to hunt down the other players using cunning and prediction to catch other players off-guard. You get the feeling from each game a new story is unfolding, that you inevitably are a part of. Especially with items that change light levels and fog in the game. Couple that with a kind of misty backstory of a web of blood and you have a weird, awesome, near-lovecraftian experience of confusion, heart-racing, and momentary relief from danger that normally only comes from single-player horror games like FNAF or Slenderman multiplayer.  For those considering buying the game, do it now, as you will need to grind up points for additional perks that make the game more enjoyable. And hey, its $20, not like other high-graphic $40 games that are multiplayer only.  You can't expect the quality to be the same for what you pay.  Plus, you help influence gameplay changes in its continuing development.  ok, enough preaching.  You might want to hold off buying the game if you want a more finished, bug-free game, as the devs are working still on game-balancing, new content, bug-fixing and the like.  A recent patch helped to balance infinite escape spots for survivors, so it is easier to play the killer now in a sense (less abuse of arena).  Perks on certain characters are overpowered versus others, meaning these perks almost never see play.  The ranking system is different from other games and takes some adjustment, as it is not enough to simply win the match while hiding in a corner watching everyone else work.  Ya gotta be brave to get pips.  Disconnects ruin the fun (when has it not in multiplayer gaming?). Perhaps some adjustment to disconnecting so that if a survivor disconnects at very start of match, a generator gets taken off the count or something.  The connections in games vary by match, meaning some matches are laggier than others,  your connection is not going to be stable every game.  Very frustrating when as a survivor you glitch into the view of the killer, or as the killer you can't hit a lagging survivor.

This is a must have for any horror fan who grew up with Michael Myers, Jason, & Leatherface. Hearing a chainsaw rev up right behind you is jarring every time.   Pros:   -- it is just fun...it's a sadistic spin on hide-and-go-seek and both roles are a blast to play. -- Addictive 'Ok, just one more match' feeling on both the killer's side & the victims' side -- Leveling system that rewards perks even after only a few matches. -- Great atmosphere -- Most online games when you get killed there is a reaction of 'Dang...he got me'. With this game it is more like: (while running from chainsaw-wielding hillbilly) 'crap, crap, crap, crap, crap, crap, crap, crap, crap....AAAAAAARRGGGHHHH!!!!'  - Then you get hung on a hook.  Cons -- I could see it getting a bit repetitious after dozens of hours in the same environments. The game could definitely benefit from more than just the single 'Fix generator, hang on hook...wait for rescue' formula...even if that variation is only a variety of new animations. -- The environments are good looking...but feel very similar to one-another.

I nominated this game for 'The Villan Most in Need of a Hug' award. At first, this might sound weird. But look a the backstories of some of the killers, most notably the Hillbilly. Anyway, this game is fun. It's hard to get tha hang of, but then once you get it you can get twelve thousand bloodpoints per game easy. I mostly play survivor, because I play with my friends, but I'm much better as a killer. Both sides are balanced, as the survivors if they know what they are doing can easily hide and not get found, or if they are found get away. The killers   are   balanced. Trapper can place traps in random places or stagegically to catch the survivors off guard but the traps can be sabatoged and avoided. The Hillbilly can knock people down instantly and traverse the map quickly, but if you avoid his chainsaw he becomes stunned and that can make the difference between life and death. The Wraith's stealth abilites can be seen through by using premonition and spine chill, and if you don't have those, his breathing is quite loud. The Nurse's teleport is easily avoided and can stun her, letting you get very far away. And finally, Michael. The one eveyone has been compaining about. Sure, he's annoying. His first stage he might as well not have a heartbeat, and pemonition and spine chill don't work. But he's slow and can't lunge very far in that stage. His second stage increases that heartbeat range and his speed, but it's still not as fast as the other killers. Now, the third stage is a bit of a weird one to try and give reasons for it being balanced. It's instant knockdown, super fast, and normal heartbeat. But it dosen't last forever. And if you can escape and hide from him, you can waste it. Then he has to waste more time stalking people to fill that bar up again. The survivors, on the other hand, aren't balanced. I mean that in the way of one survivor being better than another. Claudette's self heal is definately better than Dwight's prove thyself.   But, I do recommend it. Get it. Play it. We could always use more survivors in our ranks.

(As of when I wrote this review I had logged 10 hours into Dead By Daylight.)   My first impression of this game after having watched the trailer was one of nervous anticipation. I liked the concept and themes of the game I just didn't think it would like up my expectations. I got it on sale and decided to put some time into it. I can say now I don't regret picking up this title. It's a tense edge of your seat multiplayer expierience, where 4 survivors are pitted against an annonoumous, ruthless real-time killer. It could be the chainsaw & hammer wielding 'Hillbilly', or the masked murderer Micheal Myers, or the teleporting, screetching female killer known as 'The Nurse'. Whatever haunts the night, you will have to work together with your fellow survivors to outwit the stalker, and escape his/her domain alive. (In most cases not everyone will make it.) You do this by repairing several generators spread across the map. When enough generators are fixed they will give power to the exit gate and then you can attempt you escape. When found and pursued by the killer, survivors can use various tactics to loose the killer. They include tipping over 'Pallets' to block the killer's path hopefully even stunning the killer. Using items such as a flashlight to briefly blind the pursuer, ect. As the killer your job is obviously to eliminate all survivors or as many as you can get to. You do this by capturing survivors and impaling them on hooks, where they will struggle to stay alive as their health slowly drains. Watch out as some braver survivors may come to unhook their trapped friend. Each survivor/killer has their own perk and leveling system called the 'Bloodweb' Basically this is where you will spend your 'Bloodpoints' to level up your survivors and killers. You purchase items to help you survive, medkits, toolboxes and other perks to progress up the level system. All in all the game is fun, tense, and satisfying. Go ahead... Give it a try :D

4 Survivors vs 1 Killer, on semi-randomized maps.   First off, let's talk about Survivors, in which there's several playstyles you can have, but most importantly you don't have to be stealthy, since stealth play is poorly rewarded. If you like the idea of being chased by a Killer and trying to outwit them/juke them, then mastering the Survivor will be a rewarding task. Although if you also enjoy playing stealthily, you'll have plenty of fun trying to sneak around doing objectives(generators) and rescuing teammates.   Then there's the Killer, there's several Killers on deck already, each having a different 'ability.' Furthermore there's different takes on playing the role of Killer, some think it's as straightforward as you try to 'kill' all the Survivors, meanwhile others think it's about having fun and playing around with the Survivors (while still posing a threat of course).   Overall I would say Killer is easier to pick up, but harder to master. Meanwhile Survivor is hard and often scary at first, and later when you become more used to things, it just becomes simple repetition of movements.   And finally I would say the most important thing in this game is to have fun, and be fine with losing. There are plenty of bugs and balance issues, but the core gameplay is fun so I would have to recommend it.

Dead By Daylight is a 4vs1 multiplayer horror game where you play as either a survivor or a killer.Now I say 'horror game' but in reality I doubt you'll find the game that scary except for a few jumpscares now and then.In this game your goal is to win by either fixing 5 generators in the map and escaping through the exit gate as survivors,or killing all 4 survivors as killer. Let's go through the game.  As a survivor,you're able to choose from 5 different survivors (7 if you own both dlcs). These 5 survivors are not very different except for personalities and perks which are the game's way of progression. You see,as a survivor you get points by fixing generators,escaping,helping your teammates and etc. These points are known as bloodpoints,which you use in something called the Bloodweb to get items addons and perks. When you finish a Bloodweb you level up.   Items: These are items you get through the bloodweb or through hidden chests in the map (Note that you can only use that item from the chest if you escape with it.),these items include medkits to heal yourself or your team,toolboxes to repair generators quicker or sabotage the killer's hooks so he can't use them,and more. These can be good or bad as they have tiers like common and such.  Addons: These are things you can put in items or killer powers to empower them or make them better.  Perks: These are upgrades you can put on your survivor or killer,every survivor and killer have different perks that do different things.  Now let's talk about the killer. There are 4 killers (6 with dlcs). The killer's goal is to down every survivor by hitting them twice and carrying them to a hook in the map where the survivor will stay until a creature called 'The Entity' comes down and kills them. Basically the survivors are a sacrifice from the killers to the Entity. Every killer has a 'power' which helps them accomplish this,things like putting down bear traps or becoming invisible. They can also attach addons to their powers to make them stronger.  Now I know I'm missing a lot of stuff,but I'll stop right there and talk about the actual game.  Dead By Daylight is a fun game that can give you hours of entertainment,but only if you can endure it's problems.  Yes,the game has many. For example,finding a game as a killer can take a giant amount of time to some people (I once waited 25 minutes),the game requires you to get perks to do good in high levels,but you're only allowed 1 perk until you get to level 15 where you unlock a second perk slot,a third on level 20 and a fourth on level 25,but until you get there you'll only have one perk.There are things like hook camping,perk exploits,infinites and more that can destroy the fun of the game completely to some.  In short,Dead By Daylight is a great game with many problems that the developers are taking a while to fix.If you can get past them,you'll find a fun multiplayer game to play alone or with friends,if you don't,you will not last long before you stop playing completely.  Before I end the review I should mention that:  -The sound design is alright,not bad but not great -The graphics are fine for what they are trying to accomplish -Matches can last around 5-10-20-30 minutes or even longer,it all depends on the killer and the survivors. -Yes,teamwork is a thing but without communication (The game doesn't have voice communication or a chat system so you'll need to talk to friends with a program) it can be very tough to make it work.  Do I reccomend this game? Yes,because I believe you'll enjoy it if you can get past the problems I've mentioned. If not,do not bother with Dead By Daylight,but if you do have an itch for a game like this,look into Friday The 13th: The Game.

As cliche and lame as it may sound, it is with a heavy heart that I have to say I do not recommend this game, as much as I'd like to.  The community is toxic, the developers seem to be largely incompetent as every patch they release further breaks the game both mechanically and balance wise. The Survivors have become overpowered and the Killer will have a very frustrating time killing all of them. Yes, you can kill up to two survivors and still rank up, but the amount of frustrating work you're expected to do to accomplish this is far from fun and satisfying and is more of a chore. Most Survivors abuse infinites and exploits and swarm the hook once a person has been thrown on. And then, when you try to keep your Survivor on the hook, you're called a camper. If you fail to catch all of them, you're teabagged and laughed at.   When I first got this game, I mostly played Killer. My PC was having issues and the lag on Killer was more manageable. Once my PC was fixed, I went over to Survivor for awhile and made it to Rank 9 before the Ranking Season reset. In the past week before writing this, I ventured back over to the side of the Killer. At first it was fun, and I was having reasonable games. Sometimes I got all of the Survivors, sometimes I only got 1 or two. But everyone played fairly and all was fine. But once I hit rank 15, it all went downhill. Survivors started abusing infinites. They started teabagging. They started swarming the hook every time I put someone on. They would be abuse infinites and then accuse me of hook camping in the after game chat. Clearly the Survivors have no fear of the Killer, and the gameplay for them has suffered drastically.  The developers do not care about that, however. They have stated that their statistics show that the Killer is 'winning' rounds just as well as ever. That may be the case, but those statistics say nothing about how the experience was for the player. You can still reasonably win, but the experience you will have will be fraught with frustration and trolling.   For me, presently, the only saving grace for me is that I have enough friends to play Private Matches, where I can play with people who I can trust to play without abusing exploits or teabagging or any of the garbage that you experience in online games. But that's hardly worth the twenty dollars for this game.  The experience for the Killer needs to change. I am not saying they need to be buffed, but something needs to change, because, right now, the Killer side of the game is way to frustrating to be enjoyable. And the game depends on the Killers, needs the Killers. They are essentially the main focus of the game. It is a 4v1 horror game. The Killer needs to be overpowered to a degree for this game to work.  I hate to be that guy, but Friday the 13th is coming out soon, and this game will have serious competition. Regardless of your thoughts of the game, it will be competition. I predict a fair amount of players will migrate to that game. And when that happens, the developers will have to make a decision.  The Killers need to be the focus of the game. Not the Survivors. The Survivors are supposed to be lambs trying to escape the slaughter. The game needs to feel like that. Not like a broken game of hide and seek.

Dead by Daylight is a very fun game, but the current version of the game is too broken for me to recommend it to any of you.  Dead By Daylight is a survival game where the main goal of the game is to turn on five generators and open an exit game all while one of three possible killers try to sacrifice you to the entity.  Each map is also randomly generated which helps build tension in almost every match. Some of the structures are all the same, but they are placed differently every match. Once you hear the heartbeat and give into a chase your heart will start pumping fast.  There's also the thrill of the kill as you can play as one of three killers. The Wraith is a killer which has the ability where you can mask your heartbeat and turn invisible, but while you're invisible you can't attack anyone. The Trapper which has traps he can use to trap survivors with well placed beartraps and the The Hillbilly which has a chainsaw which gives him an infinite sprint. All killers have strengths and weaknesses and it boils down to your preference.   Now I love this game and I think it's a really fun experience, but it has too many issues to get a positive rating from me.   First of all this games community is absolute trash. It's filled with salty people, who quit as soon as they are dead and killers who aren't able to kill anyone in the match. If a killer leaves the match before you escape then you're gonna derank which is absolute garbage.  The matchmaking is also terrible. It takes forever to get into a game and is even worse for Survive With Friends, it takes around 15 minutes (sometimes even more) to get into a single game, which is absurd since most games last the exact amount of time.  The game also has bugs like character models glitching, items disappearing before the match starts and many more to list here.  Overall Dead By Daylight is an incredibly fun game, but it's too buggy right now for a positive rating. If it was more stable I would say it's definitely worth it, but as of now, wait for a lot of fixes.  Pros: + Terrifying and intense + Fun gameplay for both survivors and killers  Cons: - BUGS,BUGS,BUGS,BUGS - The abandoned survivor/killer system is broken  Final Rating  6/10

I have never seen a game as interesting and fun as this one is turn their player base away so efficiently within two days. It's absolutely astounding.  With the addition of the nurse, who can only be played by those who have bought the game (I agree with doing this entirely though), the other killers have been overshadowed by this broken, easy-mode character. There could have been no other killer concept added into this game that would say 'We only care about hunters.' more than this character does.  Sure, I'm a beginner at this game. I tried it on the free weekend to see if it were worth my time and money. Having this obscenely overpowered killer in seemingly every game I have played however (23 nurses/2 bell guys/1 trap), has been an enlightening experience as to the direction this game is going for me.  As I said, I am a beginner and a potential customer to this game. But the poorly, overlooked fact that: bringing out a character that only people who have already bought the game can play and dangling its unbalanced, sadly designed self over all who are still on the fence about buying the game, isn't going to make people want to buy the game.   All it accomplishes is this:  'If you've already bought this game, deal with this disgustingly broken character and lose whenever you want to play as a survivor, or play a game with no skill involved as the killer. If you haven't already bought our game, here have two days of losing 22 games against mediocre nurses who as any other hunter would lose their game, or be the blessed soul that goes into a game as any other hunter than the nurse. Not because you're amazing and want to have to work for your win, but because we're trying to force you to pay for our game.'  If you want to pull something like that, make it a hunter who isn't broken for the fun of it. Create the most interesting hunter you can, but make it balanced. New characters/champs/heroes/hunters shouldn't be made with strength as its top priority. Yes the strength of the character should be within reason, but what will make people want that character is how its playstyle meshes with that person, and also how interesting a character design it is. A hunter that's already much more fast than survivors doesn't need 3 blink charges or so, thus granting the ability to LITERALLY say 'No.' to EVERYTHING the survivor can utilize to get away. The fact that this hunter was allowed through even testing, let alone in game (especially during a free week), is just dumbfounding.  So buy the game if you want. It's fun, and has a great concept running for it. But it's sick that developers pull these depressing shenanigans.   For me though, I start to realize what type of person/people is/are behind the game I am buying. Yes, money is everything. Do all the sleazy stuff you people want to do for it. Keep working over the simple minded into forking their hard earned cash for your game which is obviously cared a lot about by you. Maybe next time do it in a less obvious, less player base-breaking way.

Dead by Daylight, certainly a game that seems to fluctuate in popularity since one of the biggest memes is that the game is literally 'dead by daylight' in terms of player population.  Let me make something very clear: I love this game.  I cannot recommend it, however. Not at this time.  There are plenty of reasons that I like this game: On one side of the coin that is Dead by Daylight, you can play as the Killer and live out the power/stress relief fantasy of killing some very (un)deserving individuals, or at the very least torturing them by hanging them on meat hooks in a wonderfully violent display. On the other side, you can play as the Survivors, who serve as the more tense playstyle as you keep an eye out for the Killer, fix generators, and escape (for now).  The first problem I have with the game, in my experience, is that playing as a Survivor makes the game less tense over time. Yes, in a horror game, you're supposed to be scared from time to time. In Dead by Daylight, however, as you progress in the levels of a Survivor, you start to lose that fear. This loss of fear is pounded down multiple times by several key reasons: Perks, Survive With Friends, and the matchmaking system of the game itself.  Let me clarify that I don't primarily play Survivor, I play Killer more. I try to ENJOY playing Killer, because I like the game from a more casual and fun standpoint over the ingrained competitive aspect. The three things I listed above, however, make playing Killer frustrating, to say the least. Sure, Killers get perks as well, but there's no telling of how long a given perk will remain useful as the developers update the game with buffs and nerfs.  The problem with Perks that I've noticed, at least from the Survivor side, is that certain ones are always used when available to players. Self Care, which grants self-healing at a lower efficiency compared to a Med-Kit, Sprint Burst, which is exactly what it says on the tin, and then Spine Chill or Premonition, two perks that help pinpoint Killer locations, are the established staple perks for Survivors just to compete. Saboteur was previously in this 'meme trinity' of perks as it both removed the key ability of the Trapper Killer, while also let players destroy the meat hooks that they deserve to be hung on. The only reason that I've heard of for this change in the tier of use is that it received a drop in point gain for the use of it. Bear in mind that none of the statistics or the effect itself changed, just the points gained from it. This isn't a real nerf.  Onto the Killer's side of perks, the biggest target in the community as of this moment is Iron Grasp, a perk that makes it harder for Survivors to wiggle free of a Killer's grasp when they've been taken down. This perk was (and probably still is) only used for the sole purpose of countering Saboteur, since what's the point of picking up a Survivor when all of your hooks have been demolished and the only unbreakable ones are on the opposite side of the map? The developers also seem pretty intent on removing the effectiveness of Killer perks, as for the past three dev streams on their respective Twitch channel, they either make no mention of Killer perks, or they proceed to nerf them in some fashion that doesn't affect point gains, but changes the numbers and statistics of the perk, usually lowering them. The next victims on the chopping block for this event, at the time of writing, is A Nurse's Calling, a perk that helps pinpoint Survivors being healed or are injured, Spies From The Shadows, which uses crows in the maps to give signs of recent Survivor activity when spooked.  The next key issue I mentioned was Survive With Friends. Everyone knows what this is, but for those who don't, it's basically a party system for Survivors. Who then go against a random Killer trying to host a lobby. Who then either disbands the lobby when there's 6 seconds left on the countdown because they're a SWF group, or disconnects mid-game because the unfairly precise coordination led to a literal three minute game as all the generators are popped in very quick succession. The mode itself is FINE, but only when the level of communication is matched with the Killer in some way (i.e. text-based communication from the lobby before the game starts.) This mode is unfortunately plagued by people who are usually squatting in a voice-chat medium like Skype, Teamspeak, or Discord, which usually leads to a biased game as players, dead or not, can inform others about Killer locations in a game where communication is meant to be limited and restricted to what is essentially emotes.  Lastly, the final issue. This one is something that many people have complained about, and the developers usually feign a true answer when it's asked. Matchmaking. No, I'm not talking about how the Killer hosts the lobby and the Survivors trickle in and then the game starts. I'm talking about Matchmaking from the more competitive aspect. The game uses a ranking system, separated between the playstyles for each player. Each playstyle starts at the lowest rank (20) and build themselves up to the top (1). The core problem with this that people complain about, and it comes from both sides, is that the matchmaking is broken. And it is, without a doubt. Due to my casual playing, my highest rank in the game I've reached is 19 for the Killer. I'd probably match the rank in Survivor if, at the time I would've ascended in rank, the Internet connection was more stellar than it was. There is a huge disparity in matching ranks, as a Rank 20 fresh Killer can be paired up against a full four-man team of Rank 1-10 Survivors with actual progress on their characters. This has happened to me, and it hasn't only happened to me. I'm personally miffed because developers tend to insist that the issue is being looked into and that there isn't just an influx of Survivors over Killers in terms of player count, but their solutions, if one is proposed, usually never works.  There are many other problems with the game as it stands, including the use of 'infinites' and the very soon to come, very crippling nerfs the Nurse killer might receive, but those main three seem to be the most consistent in complaints and experience, and that is where I will leave it. My hope remains in the game being straightened out at some point in my lifetime, but I harbor serious, crushing doubts.  TL;DR: Due to developer bias or incompetence, Survivors have a massive leg-up on Killers, who are being turned off from the game due to the imbalance of Survivor/Killer perk buffs/nerfs, the Survive With Friends mode, which instills toxic behavior and unfairness, and the broken matchmaking.  Behaviour, as developers, have my respect from Warhammer 40,000: Eternal Crusade, but they also have my ire from this game and their lack of balance in the community.  EDIT: It's still not that great. Also I nominate this game for the 'Villain Best In Need of a Hug' Award.

This game has the potential to be amazing. At launch, however, that potential is unrealized. The matchmaking and lobby system are an absolute disaster. I have a bit over 2 hours in this game, and in that time I have spent about and hour and 15 minutes looking for matches and about 45 minutes actually playing the game. In over 2 hours of time I have managed just 2 games. That is absurd any way you look at it.  The problem boils down to this:   -Games are hosted client-side by the Killer, who opens a lobby and waits for four Surviors to fill it. The server ends as soon as the game ends. You then have to go through the MMing all over again to find a new game.   -Playing the Killer is way more appealing than playing the Survivors, and you need FOUR times as many Survivors as you do Killers in matchmaking for equalilbrium. The numbers are obviously no where near that, thus resulting in extremely long queue times. tl:dr too many people want to play Killer.  -There is no party system in place, so you have to time when you enter the queue and hope you end up with friends. This results in a Killers lobby being filled with 4 Survivors (after a several minutes wait), only to have 2 of them immediately back out when they realize they aren't with their friends. The remaining 2 survivors stick around for a bit, but when nobody else shows up after a few minutes they invetibly leave as well, leaving the Killer to start the process all over.  I think the game needs to move to a dedicated server system, where players stick around after matches and the Killer rotates. I know I would be a lot more willing to queue as a Survivor if I knew eventually I would be able to play as a Killer without having to go through MMing again.  As it stands, if you want to play as a Killer, good freaking luck.

I had high hopes that the game would be fixed and that the dev team would listen to the community about the problems. They haven't. I can't keep being frustrated every time I open this game in hopes that I won't for once. Listen to the community, devs. They're the ones playing your game.
