Disclaimer: I played this on a Free Weekend and have not purchased the game.  Good points:  1. Spooky and atmospheric. Once you've played as killer a couple dozen times, it's not too 'horrifying' anymore, though.  2. Unique multiplayer cat-and-mice gameplay, reminiscent of other indie survival horror games where you have no weapons (Alien: Isolation, Amnesia: The Dark Descent).  3. It's fairly easy to play as the killer. Even against good teams who had 3 or 4 escapes, I almost always reached the 10,000 point mark to get a rank-up pip.  Bad points (why I don't recommend):  1. There is a huge learning curve on playing survivors. Experienced survivors are good, but new survivors are *terrible*. Three of these terrible ones might be your teammates if you play as survivor. There's some guard against this with the escape hatch that lets a sole survivor escape, but you are reliant on your team to fix two generators first.  2. The perks system gives long-time players a big advantage over players who are newer and haven't unlocked many perks or perk slots.  3. Survivors can all take toolkits or Jake (who doesn't need a toolkit), and destroy all the hooks except the basement hooks. As long as the survivors stay away from the basement, they'll always be able to wiggle from the killer's grasp before being hooked. Per the unique scoring system, the killer can still get over 10,000 points by finding and chopping down survivors, but he can say goodbye to any sacrifice points, and the survivors are nearly guaranteed to escape.  4. The scoring is unique, but not always in a good way. Your skill number doesn't necessarily increase by winning or losing, but rather by points accumulation. This appears to be based around the survivors scoring with Hopeful actions, and the killer scoring with Fearful actions, even if they don't complete their goal (escaping or sacrificing).  5. Sometimes the map can be generated with a lot of circular waist-height obstructions and pallets, resulting in a Benny Hill like situation of the killer chasing a survivor in a big circle. While the killer does move slightly faster, as long as the survivor has a good view of the killer, they can decide to drop the pallet or make a break for it anytime.  6. Grinding for perks, items, etc. is randomly generated, and there are a lot of inconsequential rewards. It can feel useless when you grind and grind and never see the perk you want.

I first noticed this game on Twitch and became interested to try it out for myself after learning how to play the game. Second, the game still feels like it's in BETA with tons of bugs and game ruining flaws. There has been no information or updates from the developer about plans to fix this.  1. Finding a match - for an online game in 2016, this feels like  Battle.net  1.0 which is 20 years old. You will likely find yourself clicking the mouse button many more times to join a game than during the actual game itself. Can the developer not afford to use their own dedicated servers? Having the killer's PC act as a host is bad on so many levels. 2. Spawn locations - the game is programmed to have the killer spawn next to survivor(s), which is no fun. 3. Matchmaking - the algorithm is terrible. The killer can see who is in the lobby but the survivors can't see who they're facing? I've been in many matches with a rank 1 killer, and 4 rank 15-20 survivors. Keep it all anonymous or all transparent. 4. LAG - The game really needs dedicated servers for various regions so it's an even playing field. I could purposely throttle my bandwidth, play as a killer, and I'll win every time. If you're in a laggy game, it's impossible to do any kind of micro control. 5. Maps - The killer does not need to see where the generators are... they are in similar spots everytime, and being able to see where the hooks are is enough 6. Camping Hooks - Is this the game the developers want? The risk/reward for helping your teammates isn't worth it with no penalty for killer's camping you. A killer can easily PIP while camping hooks. As a survivor you get the same points for sabotaging a hook than risking your life to save a teammates. 7. The flashlight - is useless. The game could use more item variety. 8. Skill checks - you WILL make noise when stopping a skill check due to you hearing the killer coming in your area. This happens maybe 50% of the time. You stop the repair/sabotage only to find out there was a skill check happening 0.5 seconds later. This should not happen! You do not even hear the auditory alert by the time you let go of the mouse button. You should be able to stop an action without a penalty like this. You absolutely cannot prevent this from happening. 9. Bugs - For weeks I've noticed bugs where you can get stuck in the map and can't move, or the killer can pick you up but also gets stuck. 10. Hatch locations - need to be easier to find, some maps they are very easy, while others are very random and nearly impossible to find in time. If the match gets to this point, why make it harder on the survivor?  Final thoughts - It's a fun game when it works right, but in my experience the amount of time you have to put in to get that experience is quite a lot. Be prepared for a lot of frustration and hours.

I really enjoy this game but it's very hard to recommend in its current state. Tons of bugs, glitches, and balancing issues can really hinder how fun this game can be, and I hate to say it, but leave it feeling REALLY unfinished. I'm really convinced that the devs are very oriented towards killers when it comes to balancing, as they never seem to get nerfed (though rumor has it that several popular killer perks are getting tuned down next patch, whenever that may be), and the meta in its current form HEAVILY favors killers.  Basic synopsis of the game: 1v4 Killer v. Survivors. Survivors have to escape by powering up 5 generators out of 7 spread across the map at random, and killers have to find and kill all of them by placing them on hooks that are also randomly spread across the map. Survivors can't really fight the killer and are just forced to run and 'juke' them using various obstacles and windows. Killers move faster than survivors, but survivors can vault windows and pallets much quicker.  Now with that out of the way, and to make it slightly more confusing, escaping or killing all survivors doesn't guarantee that you win. The game uses a Ranking system, starting from the bottom, at Rank 20, going all the way up to Rank 1, the highest. In order to rank up, you have to earn 'pips' which are rewarded at the end of matches if you earned enough points in four categories (different for both survivors and killers), which include 'objective' points for survivors who focused on fixing generators and ultimately escaping, 'boldness' for confronting the killer head-on and destroying traps and hooks. Most people consider 'winning' to be earning a pip at the end of a match. Making it possible to win even if you died, or didn't hook a single survivor.  And on top of that there's also a leveling system in place where you can level up both your survivors and killers with different 'perks' which will net you different advantages and abilities in game. You also get special one-time offerings that you can use for matches that will change things up and items you can bring with you (and bring back if you escape).  The game's a ton of fun, and thrilling on both sides of the aisle. Why don't I recommend it?  -In the patch before this last one, salty survivors who purposefully disconnected (usually as they were about to be hooked) were punished heavily by losing 3 pip and (usually) having their rank decrease, as well as rewarding the killer of the game with bonus points. This was a good change. What happens when a salty killer does the same when the exit gates are powered and they haven't hooked a single person because they've been playing terribly? NOTHING. No punishment, no repercussion. And the survivors who are auto-disconnected from the game as a result as they're about to win a hefty amount of points? You only get what you've gotten in the match thus far. No bonus points as there are in the killers' case. This is a total double standard that needs to be adressed ASAP. And sometimes, the game will bug out and have the auto-disconnected survivor lose pip for something that wasn't even their fault. Completely unacceptable.  -TONS, and I really mean TONS, of bugs and glitches. Expect to get stuck to walls, slopes and pallets regularly.  -P2P. The killer hosts the match which the survivors connect to them in all cases. Always giving the killer that slight latency advantage. You can be easily screwed over as a survivor if the killer is running their internet from a modem made out of a cardboard box in the middle of the Alaskan wilderness. You'll teleport around, mess up skill checks on generators and hooks, and the killer will nab you from seemingly ridiculous distances. The game should be running on dedicated servers, especially with how big it's become on sites like Twitch. Not to mention it opens up the gateway to lag switching and...  -Cheating. It's pretty rampant. Lots of people (both survivors and killers) are clearly cheating to get their level and rank up to Prestige 3 with only 5 hours played. As well as many blatantly using speed and wallhacks (not very fun to see killers who zip straight towards survivors from halfway across the map with no effort in finding them, or a survivor zipping and teleporting around at lightning speed making them uncatchable for the killer).  -Absolutely ♥♥♥♥ matchmaking. It's very common for Rank 20, level 1s to be paired up with Rank 1, Level 50s. The MMR in this game is pretty much nonexistent (in fact, I'm pretty sure there is none to speak of). Not to mention how long it can take to find a match. Expect up to 5 minutes of mashing the FIND A LOBBY button only to be getting a 'FAILED TO JOIN THE GAME' message.  -Survivor with friends works better now but is still very unpolished and kinda ♥♥♥. You constantly have to requeue and re-Ready up only to constantly get the same 'NO MATCHES FOUND' message. Just feels very poorly designed.  -Hook Camping  - Balance. With the nerfs to juke spots and 'infinites' that came this recent patch (which were very much needed), the game has become EXTREMELY killer-favored. 'But isn't that the point? For killers to have the advantage?' Yes, but the issue is that things are VERY tough for survivors at the moment unless they're running an ultra build from various teachable perks at max rank (Sprint burst, self-care, sabotage, something else, usually spine chill/premonition/adrenaline). If the killer spots you, getting away is nearly impossible in the majority of cases unless they're blind. The devs failed to compensate in their nerfs by adding additional pallets to maps, more places to hide in, larger patches of grass or making grass longer, or even making the tracks that survivors leave last less so that the killer will really have to be on top of their game in order to track survivors. They also haven't adressed how useless some things survivors have like flashlights and closets are. Closets make way too much noise and take time to leave, and crows begin to perch on top if you stay in one for too long, making it so that no one outside of Rank 20s who have had the game for less than 3 hours use them. And flashlights are only ever decent against wraiths, as it stuns them on top of blinding them. Against trappers and hillbillies, though? Useless. There are also many perks for killers, like the notorious No One Escapes Death (NOED) and Iron Grasp, which are just flat out game breaking. NOED can make it so that killers can instadown any survivor and move up to 5% faster after the exit gates have been powered, so are you playing like ♥♥♥♥ the whole match but still need that easy win? NOED is there for you. It just isn't an honest perk that encourages bad play. The fact that the meta REVOLVES around this perk speaks for itself. Fortunately a nerf is in the works which will hopefully even things out. But despite that, many things still need to be fixed before this game becomes truly balanced.  -Pipping for killers is just flat out easier than pipping for survivors. I can't even remember the last time I've lost a pip as killer, even on games where I didn't hook anyone. Doing things like just chasing survivors, only hitting them once and destroying barricades will almost guarantee you a pip alone. Meanwhile with survivor you can destroy 3 hooks, power up 2 generators, save 2 people from hooks, heal them up, and juke the killer for 5 minutes on end and not be guaranteed a pip.  So a super short conclusion to end the rambling: The game CAN be amazing and has a ton of potential, but the devs are very slow to fix anything (I don't even watch their streams that much anymore since they just seem to ignore repeated criticisms and pleas to fix well-known issues, like they don't even seem to understand how their game works at times), and the game is just really one-sided at the moment with a ton of bugs and issues to boot. Wait until it's (hopefully) fixed and balanced before you buy.

Great concept, implementation is mostly good, but the game suffers from a few problems that completely break it, at least for me.  First of all it gets stuck on loading screens a lot. We have 5-15min loading times sometimes and one or more players tend to leave so the game is ruined. It also inexplicably freezes in the menu when trying to create/join a game and the only solution is to restart the game.  There are also a few gameplay bugs which can completely change the outcome of the game so they can be really annoying when they happen.   The worst problem is the matchmaking though. It's completely random. Players who just started playing, who have no perks and can barely understand what they're supposed to do get matched against people who played the game for hundreds of hour, who have the best perks and know every aspect of the game. In fact, in most games you will see a bunch of rank 20s (lowest rank) and rank 1s (highest rank). This more often than not results in a one-sided game and frustration for both the experienced players and the newbies. This is really mind-boggling, since there seem to be more than enough players to have short quetimes while finding people around your skill level. A ranking system is already in place, so this issue can be addressed with minimum effort, but it's been a problem for a long time and nothing has been done about it.  The game is a lot of fun when everything goes right, when there are no bugs and people get matched with others around their skill level, but that happens very rarely. maybe once in 3-5 games. In fact, if those things I mentioned would be fixed the game would be great. But until they are I cannot reccommend the game to anyone. And that's also because some of these issues seems easily fixable, but the developers keep creating paid DLCs instead of giving them attention. This is even worse, considering the fact that, from a quick google search I've learned that people were complaining about these issues since the early access version of the game.

Very cool concept, and it could easily work. However, the way they've implemented some aspects of it is completely broken.   There is a lobby system, where you get put into a random lobby. There is no matchmaking beyond this. If you're new and playing as a survivor, you can be put together with 3 other new survivors and have to escape from a monster player that is very experienced, with many hugely advantageous perks, items, and offerings. You'll have none of these, and you cant even see the killer name, rank, perks, anything until after the game, so you can't simply try to switch to a lobby more balanced for your level. This brings me to my next point. . .  Most perks have a very clear advantage (more speed, less cooldown between attacks, break down barricades faster, see downed survivor outlines, etc for monster, faster healing, healing yourself without medic, sprinting, etc as survivor). If all perks were available for all players in the same lobby, I wouldnt find this an issue. But if you're a new player (and you can only equip 1 perk as a new player, and you'll only have a few common ones to choose from) and you're put against someone who has 4 ultra rare (read:ultra powerful) perks, your chance to win, and chance to have fun drop like a rock. Think that's enough? The high ranked players you can randomly be put up against can also equip offerings and items with attachments. Most of these are harmless, like add slightly more charges to a medkit or toolbox, or increase the chance to get a certain map. Some of these can be completely broken, including one killer offering that allows you to kill all survivors when they're downed instantly. This is basically a free win for any competent killer, as downing someone is mostly trivial, but keeping them on a hook is where the real challenge for a killer is. Do you camp the survivor on a hook, or try to stop more generators going up? None of that, because the killer used an offering that basically gave him a free win, with no counterplay, except. . .  July 3 update - A patch fixed most of the broken perk issues. Section removed.  Speaking of winning games, there is a ranking system in the game. The most poorly made one I've ever seen in a video game. I've survived a round, activating 3 generators while distracting the killer for a decent time, and still lost a rank due to only gaining 9.7k points (you need 10k to rank up, any less and you rank down instead. 3k for 3 gens, 5k for surviving, the rest miscallaneous for skill checks, being chased). Instead, people have to rely on cheeseing the game to have a consistant way to rank up, such as purposefully getting hit by the killer for a few extra points, or purposefully allowing a survivor to wiggle free and regrabbing them due to being point starved if you instead go for the objective and try to kill the enemy team as efficiently as possible. It has been one of the most frustrating experiences in all of my time playing when I deranked after hooking all 4 survivors, but because a few of them disconnected before i got the 'sacrificed' points I didnt earn enough points to reach 10k. Quite frankly, getting blasted in the face by a spinbotter in CSGO is more enjoyable.  And on to my last point... The bugs. Downed survivors can become ungrabbable, so you're forced to just watch as they crawl their way to an escape hatch while they're effectively invincible. You can also get stuck if a survivor drops a wodden pallet perfectly on you, ending your game. These wouldnt be a problem if they didnt occur so frequently.  The very, very worst part of this game, to me, is that there is actually something really, really fun and addicting in the game. Hell, I'll probably play the game some more over the week. However, I can't possible recommend this to anyone because, quite frankly, I've seen random free to play korean trash make better balancing and design decisions. I'd love to edit my review in a few weeks time for the positive, and I'd love to switch my recommendation from a 'No' to a 'Yes' because the concept really is fun and fresh. But I'll need the developer to make those fixes before that happens.

Honestly, this game has a really hooking premise. The gameplay at its core should be, and even sometimes actually is quite intense and thrilling. However, there are a ton of issues that make it difficult just to get into a game, much less actually enjoy it.  First of all, the matchmaking is absolute garbage. It flat-out doesn't work more often than not, either putting you through a lengthy loading screen only to return you back to your loadout/lobby joining screen, or just giving you a 'failed to join game' message outright. I get it, sometimes there are issues, sometimes someone else takes up the last spot in the lobby you're trying to join first, anything can happen, but for a finished product on Steam, this happens WAY too often. On the off-chance that it finally DOES put you into a game, there doesn't seem to be any actual effort to balance out the levels of survivors and the killer. Levels can make a big difference, both giving the killer a large advantage of perks obtained through leveling up over new survivors with absolutely nothing to start off, and giving more experienced survivors 'useless' teammates against what could be an otherwise impossible survival mission.  Second of all, to elaborate on the player level side of the game, there's absolutely no effort to balance things. The wraith is completely OP, having the ability to become almost completely invisible while running at supersonic speed and removing the survivors' ability to tell how far away the killer is by measuring how rapidly the heartbeat effect occurs, since it doesn't seem to occur whenever the killer is invisible. There are also 4 different survivors which are not mutually exclusive in games, and they all have different upgrade trees and unique perks and unlockables, all upgrades and unlocks are random and procedurally generated. Of course, some trees are more viable than others, and some perks and the trees they belong to altogether just seem completely useless. Why? Well...  Everything is weighed heavily in favor of the killer, and this is mostly done by allowing one thing. Camping. Absolutely every killer does it, and there's no reason for them not to. Once they hit you twice to slow you down to a crawl, it's basically game over. There's an option to try and 'wiggle free' before and after the killer sets you on a hook, but it takes way too long to actually do it successfully. There are so many hooks all around the map that it's virtually impossible to wiggle free from the killer before he finds one. And what happens when he sets you on it? He stares at you. He refuses to move his ugly mug more than 2 feet away from you.  Every single time.   Nevermind the fact that it's just plain creepy even in a video game, it cheapens the experience for everyone. There are skill trees specifically designed to help your teammates recover and escape, but it's completely nullified by a killer just camping a hook occupied with his newest captured survivor. Not only does it make this survivor completely useless for anyone playing it, and make other survivors trying to play as a team all-around useless (there goes that 'play as a team OR play selfishly premise!'), but the killer is practically forced to just stare boredly at his newest victim, because, again, there's no reason for him not to, and it ensures that they don't get rescued by another survivor. Maybe this is the way things are intended, but I find that hard to believe since there are so many opportunities where you can try to struggle/recover on your own, albiet uselessly since they have no actual effect, from the very moment after the killer gets a second hit on you. The game is hopelessly hard for the survivors when the killer does camp, and very easy for them when he doesn't camp. There's no sense of balance, no thrill, no excitement, no sense of danger or tense feelings. It's just run forever or be camped forever once you're caught. There's no dynamic gameplay whatsoever, everything just feels tedious.  After a few games, it's easy to figure out that, despite the claim for a unique and procedurally generated experience every time, every game goes the same way. Hide and try to look for generators, and if you get found out, try and run to escape (even though you likely won't since the built-in killer tracking is unreal and absurd), and once you get hit twice, you're dead, but still forced to go through the same wiggle-waggle pattern of uselessness every time. It's tedious, frustrating, and just completely stupid all at the same time.  Oh, and you're guaranteed to lose equipped items that were obtained through leveling up whenever you get sacrificed, and you'll more often than not end up sacrificed because of the reasons mentioned above. The ♥♥♥♥???  I'm now leaning heavily towards a refund since I already feel like I've seen all that I'm ever going to see in every game, especially since, according to the vast majority of this game's playerbase, the devs are allegedly reluctant to fix any bugs or balancing issues which are both plentiful in the game.  P.S. The tutorial very specifically says that you can 'hide in closets, and the killer will NEVER find you.' But he's able to open closets, find you inside, and take you with him as if he hit you three times already and picked you up, even if he never actually saw you enter the closet in the first place. lol?

I felt compelled to write a review for this game. Unfortunately it's not going to be a pleasant one.  This game was clearly released unfinished. It more than lacks in several areas that should have been polished before relase - here are the most glaring:  1) The biggest glaring issue: No partying with friends unless it's a private unranked game. This wouldn;t be so bad if the game wasn't fun only when you had a full party of 5 playing unranked, otherwise it's a boring mess. In the ranked games you are paired with complete randoms all of whom play with a Call of Duty sense of mind that they can solo the world and not bother lifting a finger trying to save a teammate. I have died countless times sacrificing myself to save a teammate or throw myself in the way of a killer and blind him only to havve myself get in a pinch later and everyone scattering to the wind. 2) No in-game chat. You might say this one was done on purpose, but when the game has a MAJOR cripple as stated in point #1 this is a necessity. They could have at least done it creatively - in-game walkie talkies that give off a noise range that the killer can here when he's close - easy to implement and effective until they fix the multiplayer partying. 3) Completely broken lobbying. This is probably one of the most frustrating issues with this game. You will spend a good few minutes just trying to get the game to ALLOW YOU TO PLAY. You click on 'Find a lobby' and the game responds with 'Failed'. Rinse and repeat a few times and then the game starts to act like it's loading to a lobby and then... you're mysteriously backk at the 'Find a lobby' screen? Click on 'Find a lobby' again and you might finally get taken in to a game with players! Everyone clicks on ready... game countdown has begun... grip your seats for a fun ride... WAIT, LOBBY CRASHED! Yeah, do that three or four times in a row and your patience for this game will have been destroyed.  It's unfortunate that this game is plagued with so many issues. It seriously is a fun game and it shines when everything works the way it's supposed to and you don't get stuck with brain-dead teammates. Unfortunately though it seems like the Developers heard that the Friday the 13th game was fundraised and decided to make a mad dash to release this - bugs and all.  Final Verdict: 4/10 with the potential of a 7/10 game. Wait for it to be patched or go on a heavy sale before wasting your well earned money.  (UPDATE: 7/24/2016) So they released the new update to allow team survivor grouping. While it does make the game slightly better - the glitches this game has are simply too numerous.  If you have a group less than 4 prepare to maybe play 1 game every 20 tries, because apparently it's too hard for this game to find a working lobby. Think it might be beter with people? Nope! It works once in every 10~15 tries.  As far as the match making goes - can someone please explain to me the point of ranks? Our group is a mix of 18~20 ranks and we are facing killers that are rank 1? The perks will make it completely one sided that it's boring.  I have to rate this an abysmal 3/10 now. It has dropped a point due to the fact that two major patches have been released since I first rated this and neither improved on their incomplete design.

OVERALL TL;DR: Game has potential, but don't buy it (even at a discount) until they patch the major issues.  ---  Can't recommend this game until they fix many things:  * Lobby/Queue/Matchmaking system is totally broken. Trying to queue to 'survive with friends' is an absolute rage-inducing nightmare. Only buy this game if you plan on playing all by yourself. You won't have the patience for the damaged queuing system.  * Infinite Loops. Survivors can find locations where they can permanently circle and avoid the killer and there's nothing the killer can do about it. Usually involves a window. The harvester on the farm maps is the best example. Survivors will simply jump on and off of it repeatedly (while BM'ing @ the killer) and the killer simply can't touch the survivor.  * Rank-up criteria for survivors. In order to rank up as a survivor, you need to earn enough points. It's not necessarily about surviving. You can play the most perfect game and rank down, or, you can get killed by the killer and rank up if you've earned enough 'blood points'. Very counter-intuitive. Takes the fun out of the game and turns it into a chore/grind.  * Unbalanced matchmaking. If you rise to a certain rank with one character as you level him/her, then switch to another character, you're suddenly at a huge disadvantage because it is matchmaking according to rank and does not take character level into account. It turns leveling up different characters into a grind of game after game of being at a significant disadvantage. No fun.  *** There are hundreds of other things wrong with this game (it feels like it's in an early Alpha state, yet it's considered 'release') but, if those three things were corrected, I could certainly recommend this game.

I can't recommend this game in it's current buggy state. In the short amount of time I played during this free weekend I've dealt with the worst hosts (whoever plays as the killer is hosting. No dedicated servers for some ungodly reason), terrible lag, the infinite loading bug dozens of times, and the inability to join a lobby. None of this is due to my connection, mind you. The matchmaking in this game is bad, and the killer being the one hosting the server is alone a huge reason for me to not recommend the game. I usually play later at night, and I have a feeling I'm getting put in a lobby with people playing across the world with dial-up or something. It's bad.  There's also not a whole lot to this game. I enjoy the gameplay for the most part, but I despise how most killers play this game. For example, going against a Trapper? 99% chance he's going to hook a survivor, place four traps all around the hook, and then stand there. Waiting for the player to go down and never giving the survivors a slight chance of saving them.  I get that that's a strategy, but it's a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ strategy. Survivors have to just leave their friend and keep working on generators since there's no way to draw the killer away from camping. There's a flashlight that's supposed to stun the killer if you shine it in their face, as far as I understand, but for the life of me and other players I've been matched with we can't get it to work. It does nothing, no matter if they're looking at it, running, standing still, etc. It doesn't affect them.  Every match plays out pretty similar, with the killer finding one player and then camping them until they die and then moving on to the next. I had one match where the killer didn't camp a hook and it was infinitely more fun. There was much more chasing and both the killer and survivors ended up getting WAY more points/XP than the former strategy. And guess what? The killer still won, which is perfectly fine because he played it in a way that was more fun and intense for both teams.  The killer can kill a survivor permanently not just by sitting and camping a hook, but by just hooking the same player twice during a match. That's it for them, they're out, and you got more points in the process.  Sadly, this camping method is too popular with players, and it really makes the game much less fun.  Also, one other thing I absolutely hated about this game is that there's no text chat. I understand why they don't want survivors to chat with each other across the map, but how come there's no proximity text chat? All I can do is point or motion 'follow me'.  Anyway, I don't recommend it. Not enough depth with the gameplay, too many bugs, and the way people play as the killer really ruins the fun for me. I'll be patiently waiting for the Friday the 13th game to hopefully do a better job.

TL;DR Just wait for 'Last Year' to come out in November. It looks much better than this game that people play like it's an e-sport.  I should've done more research before buying this game.  The basic premise is this: the 4 survivors spawn in random areas of a procedurally generated map. They must search for generators in the map and power them up, which takes time, unless you work together. Once enough generators are on, the two exit gates will be powered on. The doors must be opened, which also takes time. Once opened, the survivors can escape.  Obviously, the killer's objective is to stop this from happening.   Don't get me wrong, the idea is amazing, but the execution is bad.  You see, there's a ranking system. It doesn't do anything, but in order to rank up, you need to earn blood points. These are earned by doing a variety of things. Survivors get them for starting generators, helping each other, taking risks, and of course, escaping. The killer earns them for setting traps, chasing survivors, and of course, kills. I don't mind this system, as it helps with matchmaking.  Where it falls off is in the fact that the games don't have a winner or loser. The games just end. If you're a survivor, and you die/escape, that's it. You can either leave the game, or spectate until the game ends, which happens when every survivor has escaped or died. You get bonus blood points if you escape as a survivor, and for each kill as the killer.   But there's no feeling of victory or defeat. If I'm the killer, and I kill 2 people, did I win? Did we tie? Game doesn't say. If I'm the only survivor to get out alive, do I still lose?   This isn't a team game where 4 disadvantaged players compete to escape the one advantaged killer. Instead, it's more like ‘5 grinding players all try to level up at the same time'. It's not a team game, it's an individual game where you sometimes may have to do a team action, if you want to level up faster.  The point is this.   People don't play to win, they play to rank up.   That's all they do. They don't give a ♥♥♥♥ if they die, so long as they got enough blood points to rank up. There is no reason for me to try to come back and save you if I already have enough points to level up. I've seen people say things like, “I don't give a ♥♥♥♥ about the others unless I'm close to ranking up.” People only care about getting the next perk.  Oh yeah, there's perks. On the Reddit page for this game, people were discussing perk loadouts and the meta...in a 4v1 horror game. People actually wanna make this an e-sport, which it's never going to become.   The community is also very toxic.  There's also items that can be brought in to the game. Examples are a toolkit, which lets you repair generators faster, med kit, which lets you heal, flashlight, which can be used to blind the killer, and more. If you die with an item equipped, you lose it, and you can't use it again in later games. I kind of like this, as it adds incentive to not dying, making the game more intense, like a horror game should be. However, you may have the unfortune of playing killer against 4 survivors with medkits, and perks to make them heal faster. So good luck winning that game.   In conclusion, if you want a fun, intense, all-against-one horror game, just wait for Last Year to come out in November. That game looks way better.

Hello. This is the first time I've written a review for a steam game, but I've felt pretty scorned by this game once the honeymoon phase had passed.  The first part of the game is very thrilling when everyone is lvl 19 and 20. People make mistakes, people freak out, and it generally plays I think the way the development team had advertised it. There is one powerful killer that stalks his prey until all survivors have been eliminated or have escaped.  In my opinion it should be very rare that survivors escape. Survivors should be able to gain decent rank depending on how well they struggled to the bitter end, but escaping is something they've made far too easy.   As the game progresses into the lower ranks we find that the survivors have been equiped with so many tools and perks that there is little reason to fear the killer. Very often perks will allow them to easily identify where the killer is and which direction they're coming from with aboslutely no trade-off. Conversely the killer gains perks that mostly assist the killer once a player has been caught or has been damaged. As fun as the perks may be for the killer (like insidious perk for ambushing players), they don't assist with finding the survivors. So when the survivor has spine chill and premonition, you're never going to find a good survivor purely because the perks become their new heartbeat monitor.   I was lucky enough as a survivor to get spinechill 3 very very early. My win-rate skyrocketed on that perk alone because I could leave the area whilst my teammates had no clue why I was leaving. I knew the killer was looking my way (cloaked or not) and I could prepare to hide far in advance. This immediately kills the fear in beind hunted and just turns it into a little game of watch the spine chill detector; patience will win you most of the games at that point.  The perks for killer that tell you when a survivor is within 32 meters, and the one that allows crows to communicate with you are not terribly effective as a 32 meter radius could waste all your time looking. The crows only seem to tell you when someone is AFK.   One of the big killers for the game once you go into the lower ranks is window vaulting exploit. There's currently no cooldown on window hopping and most fo the maps are set up to allow survivors to lead the killer on an infinite loop through windows and doors where unless you're the trapper, you can't counter. You can kill all the other survivors then play infinite loop with the last survivor until one of you gets bored. THIS IS TERRIBLE GAME DESIGN. Immersion is lost, and the survivor gets all the power. Players have been known to farm killers for points and have even been know to chase the killer to egg them into following them through an infinite loop. Until this is fixed I play the game less and less.   I would really like to see most of the survivor perks go away, and really limit the perks for the killer as well. Things like Insidious, Hardended Grip *I think it's called*, and monstrous shrine are passives that only help you if you catch a survivor through a successful chase. I dislike the perks that make you completely OP in a categoy (ie. one hit knockdowns when exit gates are open).   This game is without a doubt going through an experimental phase. If you want to get yourself frustrated over t-bagging survivors that will stand on the other side of the window and crouchspam and self-heal then by all means come and play, but I think folks are looking for survival horror. Nothing horrifying about cocky survivors- the ball should always be in the killers court or there is no fear.

When I first started playing this game, I got so confused by the way the killer always caught me, and how I never seemed to figure out the way of playing as a survivor, that I deleted it after an hour and got my money back.  Then after a while I got curious again, there was something about that game that gave my brain a little itch, I had to try it again. Then poof! 200+ hours go by in a few weeks, I'm a rank 5 killer, having the time of my life in this very intriguing game. The concept is exciting, the chase is thrilling, and survivors are dying!  Then the first, long awaited update goes live, a new killer, (The Nurse), everything is still swell, and soon we start hearing rumors of yet another update, the Halloween update, featuring a yet a new killer, Michael Myers from the Halloween movies. However, this time all players who want to play the new killer (an incredibly strong one no less), has to pay for the DLC. Not like the Nurse update where we were given content we paid for, no this time you pay 25% of the games original cost.   Thats when the first red flags started popping up in my head, not good, players shouldn't have to pay for DLCs before the game is even finished properly (they basicly released the game as-is, with alot of bugs, especially a party queue bug where you had to requeue for up to an hour before getting yourself and your friends into a game).  And then again, the new update is here, with a new killer, the Hag, pay 25% of game price to play her. What do I do? Warn you all that this is what will keep happening onward, so only buy this game if you're okey with eventually paying more for tiny DLCs that the original game itself.  TRIGGERRRRD!!

Awesome concept, horribly made game. The idea of having to hide from a killer as you have to power up generators is an awesome idea and it has some other awesome editions like finding chests that bestow an item that can help you survive. But that's where the pluses end. Horrible balancing, frequent lag spikes, extremely unstable matchmaking system, falling through maps, nonsensical point system, and much more.   It's a common occurence where I have to mash the 'find match button' over and over since it can never find a game. I don't know if that's the servers not being able to handle it, or if the game is just poorly made. When I finally get in a match, it turns out I didn't just instead that my character model is stuffed inside another and now I'm forced to restart my game for a third time to find a match. Then when I finally get into a match I have a team of 2 other level 20 players, a level 19 player, all of us pinned against a level 1 killer. I don't even know how that happens.   Well when I finally manage to get into a game that's balanced skill wise and isn't lagging all over the place, there's the semi frequent chance that when the killer swings at me, they clip under the map. This of course ends with them leaving, so the match ends and I lose a pip since a match was completed but I didn't get enough points to earn a pip. How could I since the match went on for 40 seconds. Oh, and that offering for a 75% bonus for survival? Yeah now that's gone too.   But in the off chance you manage to avoid all these problems and have a stable connection and a balanced team, because of how the point system is laid out it's not uncommon to find a killer who just looms over you and doesn't swing since they get points for 'Chasing' you so that experience you were excited to get isn't going to happen this match. You can disconnect if you want but you'll lose a pip of course so instead you just have to meander along for the rest of the match and hope you get a normal game somewhere down the line.   There are other things I don't like about the game that are just personal dislikes (Such as a perk system similar to Call of Duty making it horribly unfair for new players since they will go against people who have been playing longer and have in game bonus effects helping them on top of just experience) but those are personal dislikes and not fundemental bugs that shouldn't be in a game.   Overall this game is kinda fun with friends, but the inconsistent hitboxes (Like that one flipping rock on that hill that has a massive and invisible 'hitbox' so when you try to run from the killer you get stuck on it) and SUPER buggy lobby system can make it get old pretty quick. Overall, this game is a fantastic concept and somewhere down the line can be made to be pretty good, but this game is in NO WAY worth any money out of your pocket in it's current shape.

I'm mildly disappointed in this game. I say mildly because I think with enough time this will shape up to be an extremely entertaining game. However, its technical flaws were not something I was willing to overcome. To begin with, usually when a game says it has partial controller support it's because it has a launcher or some other minor element that needs a mouse and keyboard. This is not the case.   Here, the controller is completely dead, save for the b button to go back in menus, until you get into the actual game. And even then it can be kind of spotty. There aren't any resolution options. What is there in its place is a slider that goes to 100%. Sliding this makes only the slightest bit of difference in visual fidelity.   It looked to me like it was set to 720p or even lower than that. The text and all the edges of objects, naturally, were very blurry at this resolution. This is on a 4K tv by the way. There is an auto detect option, but ticking it did not make any noticeable difference.   The game itself is great, but I play first person action games with a controller. The amount of back and forth between controller and KB+M just wasn't worth it to me. It became too annoying. But if this is not at all an issue for you, there is definitely a lot of fun to be found here.   Personally, I plan to wait until much later, when all the kinks are worked out.

This game is fun. There is very much a reason this game is very popular. Being a killer is fun because laying traps, chainsawing or sneaking up on people with your cloak can be pretty exciting. When the survivors aren't cheesing you in cheap spots then the chases are challenging and fun.   Being a survivor is fun albeit very frustrating and challenging at times. Keep in mind the killer can go faster than you so outsmarting him is key, and takes practice. Teamwork is key. This game relies heavily on everybody working as a team and watching each others back. The killers are rather overpowered too. There's a perk called No One Escapes Death. This perk makes it to where after you complete your objective of cranking 5 generators, the killer turns into a walking source of overpowered ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, and downs you in one single hit. Another reason this perk is OP, is it prevents your teammates from saving you. Once the killer downs someone and everyone is aware that he has NOED, no one is gonna attempt a rescue because they subjecting themselves to death as well.  The grind is slow but well worth it. The game is fun regardless, but the more you slowly rank up, the more perks and offerings you get and the more fun the game gets, as you can be more resourceful and helpful in aiding your teams escape.   However, the reason I can't recommend this game at this time, is because of the game breaking bugs, exploits, and the lack of an anti-cheat. I've run into a few obvious cheaters, but the worst ones are the subtle cheaters who use wall hacks. In the last 3 hours I've run into about 5 killers using wall hacks. This is extremely frustrating and game breaking. Forcing me to lose rank because of people not playing fair. Exploits.. An example of a current exploit is an offering exclusive to the Hillbilly that is supposed to make it harder to revive a survivor downed by the chainsaw, instead the offering makes it impossible to revive your teammate past 50%, so as soon as he downs someone with the chainsaw, that's it for that survivor. Bugs.. This game is plagued with them. This game is obviously unpolished and wasn't ready for release. There are spots on the map that you can get stuck on. That's right, all you gotta do is walk past some spot and bam, your character gets stuck in place and you're done. Sometimes when you escape a killers grasp, your character gets stuck in some glitched state where he hops escessively and you can't interact with anything, making you an easy target.   Once the cheaters are gone, these bugs and exploits are fixed I will happily write another review recommending this game, because when it works properly, it's a blast to play.

Just a note, I played during the free weekend... I really wanted to love this game. I loved being thrilled by the chime of the bell. I loved the adrenaline when the chainsaw revved. The way that the killer has a red glow in front of his face, that is absolutely chilling as it creeps by while you're hiding in a bush. The first hour was absolutely delightful. Both as the killer and the survivor, there is a lot of immersive elements to the game... well. Until you run into the point where being thrilled by getting killed suddenly isn't very fun, it's very frustrating. When you get stuck in a pallet as a killer, when you run into a closet instead of vaulting over that window that could have saved you, when the chainsaw guy gets stuck and everyone has a free-for-all with generators.. Overall, I hated playing the killer. As a noobie, it was fun and I thought I was decent at it, but there are little mechanics that nobody explains to you. I try to give people a chance... I try not to camp hooks, I try to be clever and have fun, but if I don't camp the hooks, they get destroyed. One game, all of my hooks got destroyed. I would have won, except, literally there was not a hook left on the map to hang people on that I knew of... Then, after I had knocked down the last two players, I decided to let them bleed out because.. well what else was I supposed to do? Of course upon reading about it, apparently in the basement there are hooks that could not be destroyed... but I didn't know that, being a scrublord noobwaffle, so I got reported.. Well, it doesn't matter anyway, because you'll always get reported as the killer. You can try to be a good killer, but unless all four survivors walk away, you literally get reported every time. I literally was able to only kill one survivor one game, and they literally reported me just because I killed them... Isn't that the point of the game..? If that says ANYTHING about the community. There will be trolls everywhere, but perhaps it was the free-weekend that this game was absolutely infested with toxicity. The amount of smack-talk that goes down before and after the games, that I experienced anyway, definitely made me think twice about buying. There are obvious go-to characters from the get-go. A couple things I learned very quickly: Don't play the nurse. Don't play the wraith. Don't play the nerdy glasses guy. Don't play the speedy girl. There is no clear outline for new players to understand what the characters do, who they are, and how to use their special abilities. New players are absolutely shafted when it comes to learning how to play the game, and they are more of a detriment to their teammates than anything else. I think there needs to be some tutorial, as in, playable tutorial. That would be nice. Along with better descriptions of the playable characters, that way people can actually tell what they want, instead of being thrown into the dark as a scrub. It also feels as though survivors are too easy to track, too easy to hunt, and too easy to kill. Unless you have an actual group of team members talking over Discord or Skype, collaborating together, it's actually very difficult to get five generators running. Not to mention, the 'camping' issue. Now, I get it, the strategy is to let that person die and turn on generators while the killer is distracted.. but when he's camped three people and you're the only one left, it's hard to get another generator running.. Not to mention, the generators take forever alone. Perhaps a 'hurry-worry' mechanic would be nice if you end up being the last one alive... Admittedly despite these issues, I would have bought it, until I found out that it comes jam-packed with micro-transaction DLC -- which add more monsters and more survivors... which I feel may have negatively influenced my idea of possibly purchasing things. I would rather see a 'Season Pass' or a 'Deluxe Edition that actually features the DLC' sort of thing. I don't like paying for a game then paying more for that game in the form of smaller transactions that give mediocre things. Also the save-game thing.. thats pretty screwed up. The one where you take your friends save-game file and instantly end up with maxed out characters? That is.. sad. Honestly when I went to look up guides for the game, I found many 'Oh just download this save game it has all the things you need lololol' or 'Ask your friend for theirs.' sort of replies, instead of.. actually getting answers and tips on how to skillfully play the game and progress my own 'save game' Overall it is worth a try, I'm always a firm believer of 'Don't use reviews to judge how much you might enjoy a game!' but... unfortunately, it feels very unbalanced, and I ran into a few frustrating bugs... the community made it very tasteless for a PvP game... making this a thumbs down.

*****Disclaimer I would recommend this game if not for the current issues with the queue systems - Once resolved I'd happily change it to Recommended********  So concept is brilliant, I get a very left 4 dead meets Gmod Murder feel to the game which obviously they was going for how the negatives currently are quite an issue.  Negatives - Queue system - You can only que as a solo 'Survivor'(join a Lobby) or 'Killer'(create a lobby) *so far I have been unable to play as the 'Killer' as the queue time's are insanely long multiple times I sat in a lobby as a killer watching people come and leave. - Hook campers - Though this may buy your team of randomers some time to escape by getting generators it leaves little room for fun if you are unfortunate enough to be caught early on, put on a hook only for the 'Killer' to stand infront of you until you die(which isn't that long really) There is literally nothing that can be done to stay alive or for anyone to rescue you if the 'killer' just stands in front of you. - interactables - again brilliant concept however sometimes they just screw you over, already in a short time many many times I've used the pallet to block the 'killer' only to have me on the wrong side of it whilst running through. - No queing as a party - This relates back to the first point but is important enough to be recognised seperately. You can only queue solo as survivor or create a private lobby to invite 4 friends, this means as a solo player you will wait in a lobby as people continuesly join and leave looking for their friends, it's beyond me how this was overlooked.   Positives. + Good soundtrack, the menu theme in particular scream 'TellTales - The Walking Dead'  + Fun with friends as per the many many youtubers videos of this with friends, it is inspired and great fun with pals + Visuals are decent for a low value game + Great feedback from the game with regards to staisfaction or escaping the 'killer' or openeing a Gate but staying behind to save that last guy. This is an amazing game!  So..... Why have i given a thumbs down?  Pro's first!  The dynamic of this game is brilliant. It gives you such an adrenaline rush and a feeling of real fear from the survivors perspective. You can feel your own hearbeat increase as your characters does when the killer is aproaching. I LOVE the fact the survivors are 3rd person and the killer is first. makes for some real funny moments when you manage to outsmart the killer when they are a meter away from you! PLaying as the killer turns you into a temporary psychopath and I love it. It is so fun to chase down the victims especially when they taunt you thinking they have the upper hand.   Now to the nitty gritty. CONS!  CAMPING HAS ALWAYS BEEN A PROBLEM! The devs reeeaaaaalllllllyyyyy need to make a way of preventing the killers camping their sacrifices because usually if they do this they kill at least 3 victims very easily and the 4th only gets away if they find the escape hatch! THIS IS SO FRUSTRATING!   There has been a bug since release that has had no update which prevents the killer picking up a survivor and therefore prevents them killing them! 4 versions in and still no sign of a fix. not good enough!  There are too many spots where the survirors can stand next to a window and hop from one side to the other infinitely so the killer cannot reach them in time. This can ruin your chances as a killer.   If a survivor leaves the game they lose their points but the killer gets some compensation and still has a chance to redeem points with the remaining survivors. If however the killer leaves the survivors get next to no points and drop rank. HOW IS THIS FAIR?!?! this should have been caught pre-release really.  The priorities and sense of achievement fall in the wrong place for the survivors. As a survivor you feel a sense of achievement on escaping the map. Unfortunately though this really means nothing. I have played a fair few matches in which all or most survivors escape yet no one has enough bloodpoints to rank up...... WTH???? Sure there is a 5000 point bonus for escaping and I think that is enough I just don't think the other actions as a survivor give enough bloodpoints to balance it. It just feels pretty crap to run out the exit dors a few feet ahead of the killer and not lose a rank. As the killer on average if I have managed 2 scrifices in a game I rank up 90% of the time (because I don't camp the hooks so people get unhooked a lot). As a survivor I have pretty much no chance of ranking up unless it was a particularly eventful round AND I escaped.  Optimisation at the moment is pretty crap. the graphics have fixed prsets making it difficult to identify culprits for framerate drops. also v-sync is default on unless you mess with config file. i did turn it of but the game runs VERY choppy without it and I assume this is why there is no official option to disable. I only get 30 fps on 1080P ultra on 2 systems that should be getting 75 (the refresh rate of my monitor) like ALL my other games get (bar some early access titles).  Finally, It can take a long time to get into the game as a survivor sometimes. it will often say 'failed to join a game' a few times and that I can deal with. The annoying occurence is how it often takes you to a loading screen after a long wait then chucks you back out. That gets frustrating after a few goes. all in all though I'm not to unhappy. compared to COD matmaking etc you get into games in a decent timescale 9 times out of 10 (I'd say within 30 seconds)  If you can deal with these issues, great game. I have played many hours of this game and will play many more. The issues are however begining to grate on me and the fact they have all been there since the beging and we have recieved no solid responses on them is the concerning factor. This is why I have chosen not to reccomend the game. Should this change I will happily change my review.

If you like losing 90% of the time then this game is for you. I've played 4v1 survival games, a great example of one (that just got poor marketing due to cosmetic day one DLC) is Evolve. Evolve shines where Dead by Daylight fails.   As a survivor you have to deal with (at this point in time) 1 of 3 killers. The main mechanic to evading killers is awareness (seeing the killer) and your senses telling you the killer is near via a heartbeat sound. However, one of the killers completely circumvents this mechanic.  I'm sorry, a CORE mechanic to your game and everyone is honestly surprised that everyone is picking the Wraith? How droll. And for anyone saying 'well I've won X games as hillbilly' or 'I've evaded the wrath plenty of times' Guess what, a good wraith is going to be far enough away from a particular spot (not moving) and unless you have the eyesight of a raven, you aren't going to spot him in time to run away.   As the survivor it's an extremely frustrating experience being unable to see your fellow survivors unless they are in mortal peril. It's also very frustrating having NO communication ability whatsoever.   I hope Friday the 13th does this time of horror survival genre better. Either way I don't care what people think about my review. My opinion and review of this game is that it's bad. So bad that I'm getting a refund for it.

So, I'll just start off by listing the negatives here.  - You can't rebind controls. At all. No text file somewhere, nothing. This is a super basic function and how it's not included is beyond me considering this spent a few weeks in 'beta'. Surely it doesnt take that long to put into the game.  - No graphics options. You get either 'Low', 'Medium', 'High', or 'Ultra'. That's it. Again, more basic options the game is missing.  - No option to queue with friends. If you want to play with friends, you have to have a full group of five, otherwise you're forced to play solo.  - No in-game voice. This becomes an issue when combined with my previous point. I'm not being hyperbolic when I say this: Dead by Daylight has the worst queue/lobby system I have ever used in PC gaming, and I'm thinking of multiplayer titles that I played back in the late 90's. It creates such a poor user experience, and my gut feeling is that I spend roughly half the time trying to enter a game, and the other half playing it.   As for the gameplay itself (once you are able to join a game), it is a very thrilling and I do enjoy it playing it. But, I absolutely cannot recommend it in its current state, since it's often times literally unplayable.

EDIT: Review revised for balance issues.  Okay let's get this straight.  - The game's buggy as hell. - Progression and matchmaking is unbalanced: new players can be stuck up against vets. - The Killer player is the host and can easily lag-switch for free kills. - The maps aren't all balanced properly. - XP progression's disabled when you're playing a custom game (to prevent farming).  However, this game is a hell of a lot of fun, regardless. It's got such potential for badass moments, like saving 3 of your friends from a creepy basement while being stalked by an invisible ghost. Or hunting and downing a player, then using them as bait to draw in their friends.  If this goes on sale and you've got a little patience, grab it. You'll certainly have some stories to tell at least.

Now I will admit, this game is an AMAZING concept for a multiplayer game. However with a bunch of issues at launch that is holding back this great game I really can't recommend it, and I will list why:  -Extremely buggy and laggy: maybe because of my terrible internet but this game has wierd bugs that can break the gameplay and cause some unfair advantages. And they better fix the netcoding for this game cause it is extremely laggy.  -Lobby issues: For some reason this 'multiplayer-only game', does not have dedicated lobbies. When you want to play as the killer you have to create a lobby instead of joining another lobby, and you have wait for SOOOO LONG to find players. Another issue is that you can't really invite your friends to a lobby before finding a match so you will joining and exiting a lobby often if you want to play with your friends. Therefore if you are the killer you will finally get survivors after waiting like 20 minutes and all of a sudden they instantly leave because they didn't find their friends... Now I don't know about you but that is one of the most infuriating things with multiplayer games!  -No mic chat: ya you heard me... in 2016 there is a multiplayer-only game that has no voice chat. So it kinda destroys any strategy for the survivors to help them win the game to out smart the killer so they better add this in a patch ASAP!  -Private matches: yes you can join your friends in a private match. HOWEVER, you won't be able to progress through your skill trees for your survivors and there is no leveling up.  Conclusion: This game is definitly an amazing idea for a fun multiplayer horror game! However its really being held back from being fun due to a lot of bugs, lobby issues, and the issues of not playing with your friends in ranked matches. This all can be fixed with patches and they better start bringing them out fast or the community will die out fast like Titanfall and Evolve. I will revisit this review when they fixed all the issues I talked about but for now, save your money and wait for this game to be patched.  Rating 3/10

EDITED 10/24/16  Alright, time for an actual review.  As you can tell, I've spent a lot more time than I probably should have playing this game, and thats because of one thing; it's addicting as all hell. But while I have gotten my 20 dollars worth out of this game, there are many problems with it that still need to be fixed, and I cannot recommend it in it's current state.  PROS - awesome soundtrack - tons of longevity due to the different killers/survivors you can play as - winning a match feels extremely rewarding for both sides - games can be ridiculously fun  CONS - the community is split into two sides and is toxic as hell, with each side complaining that the other is 'op' - ranking is broken, doesn't resemble skill level - there are spots in certain maps known as 'infinites' that allow you to waste the killer's time for however long you (or they) feel - survivors are not scared of the killer, and are rewarded for making the killer feel frustrated - there are certain playstyles for both sides that have absolutely no counter - some killers make sure that a survivor has absolutely no chance of escaping (known as hookcamping) - having rank 1 offers no reward when ranks are reset, making getting to rank 1 completely pointless  You might say that I'm stupid for giving a negative review when I have so much time on the game, but I only played for so long to see if these problems would be fixed.  Surprise, they actually fixed some problems.  gg devs

But I do think you should work to improve your toons in the game and not just swap to a completed save file.   A great game with a few issues! Overall the game is great and is one of the best survival type multiplayer games out there. Matches are never too long so it's great for players who have limited time to play every day. The game is not too graphics intensive so lower to mid-range should be able to play for the most part. After a while the killer is no longer scary but the gameplay keeps you on your toes and the adrenaline pumping regardless so this doesn't matter. Take note however, there are a lot of cons to the game right now and a lot of bugs that need to be ironed out. Balancing is still a large issue and sometimes the maps feel small when the killer can run so fast. However, with its growing popularity the developers seem to be listening to the community and trying to improve the game even without the promised weekly updates. Below I have listed some current cons to the game as well as bugs my friends and I have encountered.  One of the biggest issues at the moment is the game is very much in the killer’s favor: -Killer can see survivors ranks and levels and just leave -If the killer has iron grasp it won't matter if you get rid of all the hooks you can't wiggle out -It the killer has a memento mori you will more than likely lose the game -If you disconnect the killer gets points, if the killer disconnects you get nothing -The killer is the host of the game so if he lags, you all lag, and lag switches seem to be a rampet issue -If the killer has No One Escapes Death then forget opening gates unless at least two of you are alive and even then you risk death (Yes I understand the killer needs some advantages because he is in first person and therefore as a smaller field of view, but some of the killer’s current perks are just very overpowered. Note: Some of these perks are due to be nerfed soon!)  The game also has a lot of bugs: -Sometimes you throw a pallet down and end up on the wrong side -You will try and vault a window and end up looking like you climb a wall -You can get stuck inside hooks after being saved or even stuck in the ground -You will get downed and get glitched to where your teammates can't heal you and the killer cannot pick you up  Matchmaking is terrible: -As stated earlier the killer will leave if the survivors are too high rank waiting for lower ranks -Sometimes a group of 4 rank 18-20 survivors will get matched with a rank 1 killer -Good luck finding games sometimes in survive with friends -You don't stay in a que but instead have to constantly ready up (Ready Sim 2016: you will spend 30% of the game just trying to find a match 45% if you're playing survive with friends)

This game was built as a non traditional co-op game, but then one was poorly rushed out breaking everything in the process. But as you rise in the ranks you meet more and more people who know and use exploits and un-fun tactics to win at any cost. Dead by Daylight might be great someday, but until then please save your money. Friday the 13th: The Game is coming early 2017...

I dont write alot of reviews, but I can't help write a review for this because I feel people should know what they're getting into before buying. I'll try to keep this as short and simple as i can: This is an extremely addictive and ridiculously fun to play game but it suffers from a lot of issues that moslty stem from unresovled bug issues, laggy killers/survivors, poor map design, and the fact that anyone and their mom can cheat.   1. The cheat engine is a joke and ppl can easily get around it resulting in speedhacking survivors/killers with ESP who can see everyone on the map with boxes highlighting them. Seriously go look at youtube for a second and find some dead by daylight hacks. Its downright damning to anyone who wants to play the game without cheating or without said cheaters. I have read its best to report them on steam when u find a suspected hacker. Also, dont forget the lag can cause it to look like the survivor or killer is lag swithcing or speedhacking so its best to just report suspcted cheating and let steam deal with it.  2.This game has p2p host, introduce laggy killers and survivors who seem to warp around the map, a dedicated server or servers would solve this issue but i would not expect that to happen anytime soon. Until that happens or if it never does you are at the mercy of your killer's ping most of the time. Also, going back to the first point, the p2p+easy anticheat= anyone can cheat without getting caught.  3.Balancing has been an issue since launch and will continue to be so as long as they keep making unneccesarry nerfs and buffs to the wrong things instead of fixing the real issue at hand. In case a dev reads, my advice is to make a tier system and put perks into tiers where u can only have one perk from each teir and put perks like Self care and Sprint burst in the same tier. Do the same with Save The Best For Last and Unrelentless on the killer side. This will break up the pallete camping and machine gun builds that players are abusing atm. Just Food For Thought.  4.Prob the biggest issue I would like to address has nothign to do with the game itself oddly. And welcome the community is toxic AF rant. Bring a thick skin to the party bc the salt is strong in the post game lobby. From both sides its getting really bad. Looking at the profiles of other players has become a regular chore before starting a match and what i have found is that DBD has inhertied one of the most toxic gaming communities of all time, looking at you CSGO. Yes alot of the players you will find on DBD are also the same trolls from one of the worse communities ever known to gaming. On top of all that SWF(survive with friends) groups will use discord to gaing the upper hand agaisnt the killer and then talk mad ♥♥♥♥ in the post lobby. If you plan to play with friends on discord know that it takes most of the difficulty out of the game and is pretty much the equivalent to neutering the killer. I do not know why this is a feature that does not have its own mode. SWF should not be allowed in ranked matches imo. Just simply make a third mode thats a mix beteen play with friends and ranked matches and let it have its own rankings. This way a killer can play a mode where not every match is a match against high ranking 4 man groups who basically ♥♥♥♥ on the killer bc of OP perk combos and communication. If you play a round against 4 people on discord all using decisive strike sprint burst and self heal then you will understand.   Summary: Dead by Daylight is a fun and addictive game with a lot of issues such as OP perk combinations, a basically non existant anticheat engine, a toxic community, no dedicated servers, the very broken SWF feature, and much much more.
